{"uri": "2024-06-394532936", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "10:16:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T10:16:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T10:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/nvidia-remains-the-stock-to-own-in-this-bull-market-1033489905", "title": "Nvidia Remains the Stock to Own in This Bull Market", "body": "InvestorPlace - Stock Market News, Stock Advice & Trading Tips\n\nDespite its big gain on the year and recent 10-for-1 stock split, chipmaker Nvidia's (NASDAQ:NVDA) shares have more room to run and remain a buy for investors looking to make money in this bull market.\n\nNvidia stock has enjoyed multiple catalysts this year -- from blockbuster earnings and the stock split to the launch of new artificial intelligence microchips and achieving a $3 trillion market capitalization.\n\nNow, Nvidia has a new catalyst as exchange-traded funds rebalance and add more of the stock to their holdings. The Technology Select Sector SPDR Fund (NYSEARCA:XLK), for example, is adding more than $10 billion worth of Nvidia shares as it rebalances at the end of the second quarter.\n\nAt the same time, 40 Wall Street analysts rate Nvidia stock a \"strong buy\" and see more upside ahead. There are no \"sell\" ratings on the stock despite the fact that the share price has risen 172% this year and nearly tripled in the last 12 months.\n\nHuge Demand\n\nThe outperformance in Nvidia stock is being driven by huge global demand for its microchips and processors, which power AI applications and models.\n\nThe massive demand has translated into escalating sales and profits at Nvidia. The company most recently reported that its revenue in the first quarter of this year rose 268% from a year ago.\n\nAt the same time, the company's profit was up 646% year-over-year.\n\nNvidia reported that sales at its data center unit, which includes it's AI microchips and semiconductors, rose 427% from a year earlier to $22.6 billion. However, Nvidia isn't a one-trick pony.\n\nThe company also highlighted strong sales of its networking parts that are used to connect clusters of microchips and processors. Nvidia said that it had $3.2 billion in networking revenue during Q1, which was three times more than sales recorded during the same period of 2023.\n\nChips used in video games saw their revenue rise 18% during the quarter to $2.65 billion.\n\nNew AI Chips\n\nWhile Nvidia is getting a boost from all areas of its business, demand for its AI chips is what's driving the company and its share price to new heights.\n\nTo keep pace with the soaring demand, and to keep competitors at bay, Nvidia has been rolling out new artificial intelligence products at a brisk clip. Currently, Nvidia controls about three-quarters (75%) of the worldwide market for AI chips and semiconductors.\n\nIn March of this year, Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang introduced new AI graphics processors called the \"Blackwell\" series. The first Blackwell chip called the \"GB200'' will ship later this year.\n\nHowever, Nvidia has already unveiled the next microchip that will eventually replace the Blackwell chip. Called \"Rubin\" chips, the successor to the Blackwell series will be Nvidia's most powerful and energy efficient chip yet.\n\nThe Rubin chips are scheduled to ship in 2026 and highlight the speed at which Nvidia is updating its technology in order to stay a step ahead of rival chipmakers.\n\nBuy Nvidia Stock\n\nNvidia has largely powered the current stock market rally that began in October 2022. The company's shares have nearly tripled in the past year, undergone a mighty 10-for-1 stock split, and maintain a \"strong buy\" rating among analysts.\n\nThe company continues to have a huge growth opportunity ahead of it with its AI microchips and management is doing everything it can to capitalize and meet global demand. Nvidia remains the stock to own in this market. Its shares are a buy.\n\nOn the date of publication, Joel Baglole held a long position in NVDA. The opinions expressed in this article are those of the writer, subject to the InvestorPlace.com Publishing Guidelines.\n\nMore From InvestorPlace", "source": {"uri": "markets.businessinsider.com", Nvidia shares are up nearly 174% so far this year.\n\nContract chip manufacturer Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp gained as much as 4.34% as the upbeat investor sentiment over Nvidia spilled over to tech stocks in Asia.\n\nTSMC manufactures Nvidia's high-performance graphics processing units that help power large language models -- machine learning programs that can recognize and generate texts.\n\nTaiwan's Hon Hai Precision Industry -- known internationally as Foxconn -- gained as much as 4.78%. It has a strategic partnership with Nvidia to build \"AI factories,\" which will use Nvidia's chips in a whole range of applications, including electric vehicles and LLMs.\n\nJapanese tech stocks also gained, including semiconductor testing equipment supplier Advantest, which counts Nvidia among its clients, according to Bloomberg data.\n\nThe stock saw a gain of as much as 3.86% on Wednesday, despite Bloomberg reporting that Nvidia accounts less for 1% of Advantest's total sales.\n\nJapanese investment holding company Softbank Group Corp, which owns a stake in chip designer Arm, whose architecture is used in Nvidia chips, saw shares climb as much as 4.19%.\n\nNvidia's value chain also extends to South Korea, namely, memory chip maker SK Hynix and conglomerate Samsung Electronics.\n\nSamsung shares climbed as much as 3.38%, while SK Hynix gained as much as 7.04%.\n\nSK Hynix provides high bandwidth memory (HBM) chips to Nvidia, which are used in AI chipsets. Until March, the company was the sole known supplier of HBM chips to Nvidia, Reuters reported.\n\nIn June, Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang reportedly told journalists that the company was studying HBM chips made by Samsung and U.S. firm Micron Electronics.\n\nSamsung had earlier refuted an exclusive Reuters report that that its chips were failing Nvidia's tests due to heat and power consumption issues, At the end of the trading day today in the US, Nvidia found itself in that number one spot.\n\nCNBC reports that the graphics chip maker surpassed the market cap of the previous most valuable company, Microsoft, today. That was because Nvidia's stock price went up by a significant 3.6 percent today, which gave the company a market cap of $3.34 trillion. That was enough to get ahead of Microsoft's market cap of $3.32 trillion. Its share price went down by 0.45 percent today.\n\nIronically, Microsoft is a huge customer of Nvidia's products, particularly its GPUs that it used to power its AI services like Copilot in its data centers. Indeed, the main reason why Nvidia's stock price continues to go up and up is that its GPUs are used in 80 percent of those AI data centers from Microsoft, Google, OpenAI, and more companies.\n\nEarlier this month, Nvidia went over the $3 trillion market cap for the first time and surpassed Apple to become the second most valuable publicly traded company. At the end of today's stock trading, Apple came out as the third most valuable publicly traded company behind Microsoft and Nvidia with a market cap of $3.29 trillion.\n\nNvidia recently launched a 10-for-1 stock split, so that more people could afford to actually purchase some shares in the company. One person who has a lot of Nvidia shares is its co-founder and CEO Jensen Huang. After today's trading, Forbes estimates Huang's overall net worth to be a whopping $118.4 billion. Forbes says that now makes him the 11th richest person in the world, ahead of people like Dell founder Michael Dell.\n\nHowever, he's still behind some major tech industry titans, like Microsoft With this surge, the company's market value soared to $3.34 trillion, nearly doubling since the beginning of the year. This dominance positions Nvidia as a leader in providing GPUs for gaming and other demanding graphical applications.\n\nIn fiscal year 2024, Nvidia reported annual revenue of $60.9 billion, marking a significant increase compared to previous years.\n\nJensen Huang, Nvidia's charismatic chief executive, has gained celebrity status in the tech industry, often likened to Taylor Swift for his passionate presentations and influential leadership. The top stocks have jockeyed all month for the pole position, with Nvidia finally edging past both of its big-tech peers.\n\nEarlier in the month, Nvidia capped Apple by market value for the first time since 2002, and the two went back and forth in rankings in recent days. Last week, Apple also overtook Microsoft to trade in the top spot briefly.\n\nALSO READ| H-1B and L-1 visa extensions could weigh thousands of dollars heavier on US employers, according to new DHS proposal\n\nThe ranking is yet another reminder that AI is the top focus of many investors. Nvidia is seen as the biggest and earliest beneficiary of the technology as it dominates the market with its highly sought-after chips that help power data centers running complex computing tasks required by AI applications. Demand for its H100 accelerators are surging and helped drive the chipmaker's sales up by more than 125% last year.\n\nMicrosoft, for its part, is also seen as an early AI winner given its investment and partnership with OpenAI, which created ChatGPT. And, this week, Apple shares rallied after the iPhone maker finally unveiled its plan for using the technology, appeasing investors at long last.\n\n\"We believe over the next year the race to $4 Trillion Market Cap in Tech will be front and center between Nvidia, Apple, and Microsoft,\" Daniel Ives, analyst at Wedbush Securities, wrote in a note.\n\nNvidia's surging stock price has made co-founder and Chief Executive Officer Jensen Huang one of the world's richest people. His net worth has climbed nearly $75 billion since the beginning of the year to $119 billion, putting him in 12th place on the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. That's the biggest gain among his billionaire peers.\n\nInvestors, alongside Huang, argue that Nvidia is more than a chipmaker.\n\nALSO READ| Why much of the US is sweltering: 'Heat dome' explained\n\n\"They're not just selling chips, they're selling systems,\" Michael Lippert, vice president and portfolio manager at the Baron Capital Inc., said in an interview, pointing to the company's proprietary software and development ecosystem.\n\nNvidia's swift climb to the top has been record breaking, as the company is one of the few firms to have demonstrated significant revenue growth from AI. The company's stock has risen around 176% this year, meaning the value of the shares far surpasses previous periods, including the first six months of 2023, when insiders sold about 848,000 shares, according to Bloomberg. The 770,000 shares are the most sold in a half year period since then, the publication reported, citing data from The Washington Service.\n\nIn May, Nvidia beat Wall Street's expectations, reporting record first-quarter revenue of $26 billion for fiscal year 2025 -- up 262% from the previous year. After its first-quarter earnings report, Nvidia's stock price opened above $1,000.\n\nNvidia's Hopper chips, which are used for training and inferencing some of the world's most powerful artificial intelligence models, have propelled the company to become the first chipmaker to reach a $2 trillion market cap in February, before crossing $3 trillion earlier this month. Demand for Nvidia's chips amid the AI boom have driven it to become the third-most valuable company in the world behind Microsoft and Apple. In March, Nvidia unveiled its chip successor, Blackwell, which it said will start shipping in the second quarter of this year, and be with customers in the fourth quarter. Nvidia chief executive Jensen Huang said the company will see revenue from its Blackwell AI platform this year.\n\nEarlier this month, Huang announced Blackwell's successors, the Blackwell Ultra chip for 2025, and next-generation AI chip platform, Rubin, coming in 2026. {"uri": "8185013637", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "09:23:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T09:23:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T09:22:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.fool.com/investing/2024/06/19/prediction-nvidia-five-trillion-generative-ai/", "title": "Prediction: Nvidia, Now the World's Most Valuable Company, Will Hit a Market Cap of $5 Trillion by 2026 | The Motley Fool", "body": "The stock has been on a meteoric rise over the past 18 months, soaring 8,280% since the start of 2023 (as of this writing). Nvidia has been riding the wave of accelerating adoption of artificial intelligence (AI), providing the graphics processing units (GPUs) that are the gold standard for powering the systems responsible for AI training and inference.\n\nThe company also completed a 10-for-1 stock split that was a hit with investors, driving the stock even higher.\n\nWith gains of that magnitude, it would be easy to conclude that the opportunity has passed, and the easy money has already been made. I think that view could be a costly one, as I predict that Nvidia's market cap is headed to $5 trillion, which would push its share price above $203, representing upside of 50% compared to the Tuesday's closing price.\n\nLet's take a look at how Nvidia could get there in the not-too-distant future.\n\nGenerative AI burst onto the scene last year, touting the ability to streamline and automate time-consuming and mundane tasks. The potential to increase worker productivity was met with cheers from corporate America as companies race to adopt these next-generation algorithms.\n\nNvidia supplies the processors with the computational horsepower necessary to run these AI systems. The company has been scrambling as demand has far outstripped supply. The supply shortages are beginning to ease as Nvidia has worked with its partners to ramp up production.\n\nFurthermore, the company has a virtual monopoly on machine learning (an earlier branch of AI) with an estimated 95% share of the market, according to data compiled by New Street Research. This helps explain why demand for generative AI quickly became a boon to Nvidia, given its proven expertise in the area.\n\nThere's more: The need to upgrade data centers to handle the rigors of AI has been at the heart of the current demand cycle, which is expected to continue. The vast majority of generative AI processing takes place in data centers and in the cloud, and it's estimated Nvidia controls 92% of the data center GPU market, according to IoT Analytics.\n\nRobust growth is expected to continue across the data center market, climbing from $302 billion in 2023 to $622 billion by 2030, according to Prescient and Strategic Intelligence Market Research. As the leading provider of data center GPUs, this trend favors Nvidia.\n\nLet's not forget, however, that it all began with the humble GPUs used to render lifelike images in video games, another area Nvidia dominates. Despite growing competition, it maintains a healthy lead in the industry it pioneered. In the first quarter of 2024, it controlled an 88% share of the discrete desktop GPU market, according to Jon Peddie Research.\n\nAs inflation subsides, the pent-up demand for new, state-of-the-art graphics cards will drive a new upgrade cycle for Nvidia gaming chips. Sales of gaming GPUs are expected to soar from $2.7 billion in 2023 to $11.7 billion by 2028, according to Mordor Intelligence. As the market leader, this trend also favors Nvidia.\n\nThe company has a number of other opportunities that could take off, including self-driving cars, professional visualization, and quantum computing, which currently make up just a small percentage of the company's overall sales.\n\nLastly, the Nvidia GB200 Grace Blackwell Superchip will be released later this year, setting a new standard for AI processing. The largest hyperscale cloud-infrastructure providers are already lining up to pay top dollar for these state-of-the-art AI platforms, which suggests the company will remain as the AI market leader.\n\nNvidia currently has a market cap of roughly $3.34 trillion, which means it will require stock price gains of roughly 50% to drive its value to $5 trillion. That seems like small change compared to its 2024 year-to-date gains of 174%, so it's likely just a matter of time.\n\nAccording to Wall Street's consensus estimates, the company is expected to generate revenue of $120.5 billion in fiscal 2025 (which began in January). That gives the stock a forward price-to-sales (P/S) ratio of roughly 28. If that P/S remains constant, Nvidia will need to generate annual revenue of roughly $180 billion to support a $5 trillion market cap.\n\nCoincidentally, Wall Street is already guiding for revenue growth of 98% in fiscal 2025 (this calendar year) and 33% in fiscal 2026. If the company hits those targets, it could achieve a $5 trillion market cap as early as 2026.\n\nDon't take my word for it. Rosenblatt Securities analyst Hans Mosesmann just reaffirmed his buy rating on Nvidia stock and assigned a Street-high $200 price target, citing greater demands for AI software and the release of the Blackwell architecture later this year.\n\nIt's important to note that there are no guarantees. Any failure to achieve investors' lofty ambitions -- real or perceived -- would likely be met with a quick and potentially brutal sell-off. On the other hand, it's just as likely that Nvidia's market dominance could continue, and the timeline calculated above could end up being conservative.\n\nThe stock is currently selling for 51 times forward earnings, which might seem expensive, but that doesn't take into consideration the stock's 27,570% gains over the past decade. To be clear, there's little chance the next decade will be as lucrative as the past 10 years have been.\n\nThat said, given Nvidia's dominant place in the industry and the gale-force secular tailwinds at its back, the chances it will be a market-beating investment in the coming years are exceptional.", "source": {"uri": "fool.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Motley Fool"}, "authors": Nvidia just crossed Microsoft to become the world's most valuable publicly traded company as investors eye the tech giant dominating the boom of Artificial Intelligence tech.\n\nNvidia's stock price rose by 3.5% to $135.58, while the chip maker's market capitalization reached around $3.34 trillion at the end of trading on Tuesday, surpassing the value of Microsoft, which stood at $3.32 trillion, according to CNN, with Apple remaining in the third spot at $3.27 trillion.\n\nThe growth of Nvidia has seen the firm transform from one that is primarily recognized for manufacturing processors for video games into a worldwide dominator in the expanding industry of Artificial Intelligence, with major tech corporations looking for Nvidia's chips to function as the bedrock of this technology, skyrocketing its revenue.\n\nNvidia is among the most prominent of the Magnificent Seven firms, which are the technology behemoths that have propelled a significant portion of the stock market's profits since the artificial intelligence mania struck Wall Street last year, the stock of the company has increased by almost 174% for the year and was named the greatest performer in the S&P 500 index in 2023 due to its performance.\n\nAfter reporting a year-over-year growth in revenue of 262% and a year-over-year gain in profits of 462% in its most recent quarter results a month ago, Nvidia has recently concluded a 10-for-1 ratio stock split on June 7.\n\nJensen Huang, CEO of Nvidia, spoke on the future of AI during the COMPUTEX conference earlier this month saying \"we're at the cusp of a major shift in computing.\" Huang noted that \"the next wave of AI is physical AI. That's as the artificial intelligence craze has gripped Wall Street, and Nvidia's quarterly earnings show no sign that the rush to stock up on AI chips isn't slowing down.\n\nBut relying so much on one stock also represents a big risk, Sl\u00f8k warned.\n\n\"Such a high concentration implies that if NVIDIA continues to rise, then things are fine,\" he wrote in a note on Wednesday. \"But if it starts to decline, then the S&P 500 will be hit hard.\"\n\nBecause the S&P 500 is weighted by market cap, even relatively minor wobbles from behemoths like Nvidia, Apple, and Microsoft can move the needle on the broad stock market index.\n\nAnd as retail investors increasingly load up on S&P 500 index funds, that means exposure to Nvidia -- for better or for worse -- is growing as well.\n\n\"The bottom line is that the extreme concentration of returns in the S&P 500 makes investors more vulnerable to single headlines impacting the one stock driving index returns,\" Sl\u00f8k added.\n\nThis isn't the first time he has sounded the alarm on the stock market's dependence on Big Tech.\n\nWhen Nvidia's market cap topped $2 trillion for the first time ever earlier this year, Sl\u00f8k compared tech valuations to the bubble seen during the dot-com era.\n\n\"The top 10 companies in the S&P 500 today are more overvalued than the top 10 companies were during the tech bubble in the mid-1990s,\" he wrote at the time.\n\nOthers on Wall Street are also growing more skeptical about Nvidia's valuation and its attractiveness as an investment after the stock's epic rally.\n\nBut Nvidia stock bulls remain. Beth Kindig, lead tech analyst at the I/O Fund, sees more astronomical gains in the coming years, predicting its market cap will surge more than triple again to $10 trillion by 2030.\n\nMeanwhile, Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang continues to surprise Wall Street, most recently by laying out a rapid cadence of new AI platforms.\n\nEarlier this month, he said Nvidia plans to upgrade its AI accelerators every year as he announced the Blackwell Ultra chip for 2025 and a next-generation platform in development called Rubin for 2026.\n\nThis story was originally featured on Fortune.com", "source": {"uri": "2024-06-394851194", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "14:51:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T14:51:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T14:43:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://ca.finance.yahoo.com/news/q-did-nvidia-become-world-144344294.html", "title": "Q&A: How did Nvidia become world's most valuable company?", "body": "Nvidia, the US computer chip firm, has moved ahead of tech giants Microsoft and Apple to become the most valuable company in the world.\n\nHere is a look at how the California-based company achieved this.\n\n- What has happened?\n\nOn Tuesday, Nvidia's share price hit nearly 136 US dollars (\u00a3107), giving the company an overall valuation of 3.34 US trillion dollars (\u00a32.63 trillion).\n\nThis made the company more valuable than Microsoft, having also overtaken fellow tech giant Apple earlier this month, and become the most valuable company in the world.\n\n- Why has the firm become so valuable?\n\nA computer chip giant previously best known for making graphics cards, Nvidia has in recent years come to dominate the market in artificial intelligence (AI) chips - specifically those needed to train and run the powerful AI models that run generative AI software such as OpenAI's ChatGPT.\n\nGenerative AI has become the key battleground in the tech space over the last 18 months, with some experts saying it could be as pivotal an innovation as the internet itself in the years to come.\n\nThe excitement around the technology has sparked a battle between some of the world's biggest companies - Apple, Amazon, Google, Meta, Microsoft and others - to build new AI products.\n\nWith Nvidia as the key maker of AI chips, this has substantially boosted the firm's sales and profits, with its stock price further helped by some investors believing it could go higher, with demand for AI expected to increase further.\n\n- How fast has Nvidia's value grown?\n\nWhile its share price has been steadily rising for several years now, it has only been this year that it truly took off.\n\nIts value has more than doubled in 2024 to now sit at nearly 136 US dollars a share.\n\nIn contrast, at the beginning of 2023, it was priced at less than 15 US dollars a share, and five years ago it was less than four US dollars.\n\n- Is it likely to keep growing?\n\nMany investors believe the demand for AI is only going to increase, meaning Nvidia's value could rise still further, with some believing the company is now in a direct race with Microsoft and Apple to be the first to reach a four trillion US dollar valuation over the next year.\n\nBut others have questioned whether further big gains in the future are likely, given the increasing competition it is and will likely face in the months and years to come as tech giants begin to build and use their own AI chips, existing rivals catch up and new firms emerge as key players in the AI chip market.", "source": {"uri": "ca.finance.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo! Surpassing Microsoft, the chipset manufacturer now holds a valuation of $3.348 trillion as of the time of composing this article. Nvidia climbed two positions, displacing both Microsoft and Apple. The sophisticated chipsets developed by Nvidia play a pivotal role in the competition for dominance in the artificial intelligence (AI) market.\n\nAlso Read: Samsung Galaxy S24 FE leaked renders reveal 6.65-inch display and triple rear cameras\n\nThe company has experienced an impressive growth rate of 3.92 percent, while its stock price remains steady at approximately $136. This accomplishment follows Nvidia's surpassing of Apple, the previous second-place holder.\n\nIn contrast to Microsoft's modest 19 percent increase, the company's stock has skyrocketed by a remarkable 173 percent this year. This surge can be attributed to the high demand for Nvidia's top-tier processors, which are crucial for the development of artificial intelligence.\n\nThe limited supply of these processors has resulted in a significant rise in the company's stock value. Within a span of just five months, the company's market capitalization has surged from $1.21 trillion on January 6, 2024, to its current value of $3.326 trillion.\n\nAs generative AI continues to play a pivotal role in the technology industry, Nvidia stands at the forefront. Leading cloud service providers heavily rely on Nvidia's GPUs to train and operate AI applications.\n\nWith a client base that includes approximately 20,000 start-ups, as well as renowned companies like Microsoft, Alphabet, and Amazon, Nvidia is the preferred choice for those seeking cutting-edge AI chips.\n\nNvidia has unveiled two innovative platforms that have the potential to transform the field of computing:\n\nBlackwell Platform: The Blackwell platform is designed to enable real-time generative AI on trillion-parameter large language models. It is projected to deliver cost and energy savings of up to 25 times when compared to its predecessor.\n\nRubin Platform: During Computex 2024 in Taiwan, Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang revealed the Rubin platform. This platform features new GPUs and a central processor named 'Vera.' {"uri": "8185628427", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:12:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:12:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:11:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/money/article-13547407/How-make-money-new-largest-company-world-Nvidias-shares-soared-3-477-year-experts-say-not-late-invest-Read-guide.html?ns_mchannel=rss&ns_campaign=1490&ito=1490", "title": "How you can make money from Nvidia - the world's new largest company", "body": "It is the stock market success story of the century - and one that will shape the rest of our lives.\n\nSince going public on the eve of the Millennium, computer chip designer Nvidia has come from nowhere to become the world's biggest company.\n\nThe remarkable milestone was passed yesterday when its share price soared to a new high, overtaking tech giant Microsoft to value the Silicon Valley pioneer at $3.34trillion (\u00a32.6trillion).\n\nTo put that into context, Nvidia's stock market valuation now trumps the annual output of the entire British economy.\n\nIt's been a truly stratospheric rise.\n\nIn February, Nvidia became the fastest company ever to go from $1trillion to $2trillion. Astonishingly, it took just eight months.\n\nJensen Huang, 61, the Taiwan-born electrical engineering graduate who founded Nvidia alongside microchip designers Chris Malachowsky and Curtis Priem\n\nNvidia originally made computer chips for video game software, but has since expanded its horizons to dominate the AI sector\n\nThe latest surge means the company - whose chips have turbo-charged the meteoric rise of artificial intelligence (AI) - has seen its share price rise from under $4 in June 2019 to almost $136 today. That's an incredible 3,477 per cent increase in five years.\n\nCan British investors still make a profit on Nvidia shares, or have you missed the boat if you don't already own them?\n\nExperts say that there may be more good gains to be had - though the stock is not for the faint-hearted.\n\n'We have for some time thought Nvidia would become the most valuable company in the world,' says Stephen Yiu, who manages the \u00a31.1billion Blue Whale Growth Fund.\n\n'In overtaking Microsoft, it has now achieved that remarkable milestone.'\n\nYiu has put his money where his mouth is - and made 'more than \u00a3100million' backing the AI pioneer in just three years.\n\nBut the company's latest leap has taken even him by surprise.\n\nHe recently thought it might take Nvidia another two years to become the world's biggest company... it took just over two weeks.\n\nSo can Nvidia's amazing run continue? Yiu, for one, is happy to keep it as his fund's biggest single holding.\n\nHe argues that investors are still too focused on the microchips side of the business while overlooking the importance of Nvidia's associated software, where he thinks sales growth is likely to be faster over the next decade.\n\nExperts have been busy upgrading their price targets on the back of Nvidia's latest share spike.\n\nRosenblatt Securities analyst Hans Mosesmann thinks the shares could hit $200, which would put Nvidia's value within touching distance of $5trillion.\n\nHe argues that investors are still too focused on the microchips side of the business while overlooking the importance of Nvidia's associated software, where he thinks sales growth is likely to be faster over the next decade.\n\nCathie Wood of Ark Invest and an early backer of Nvidia reckons the market for AI software could be worth $13trillion by 2030.\n\nWood famously sold out of Nvidia last year, a decision that is estimated to have cost her flagship technology fund up to $800million in potential profits.\n\nCathie Wood of Ark Invest and an early backer of Nvidia reckons the market for AI software could be worth $13trillion by 2030.\n\nWood famously sold out of Nvidia last year, a decision that is estimated to have cost her flagship technology fund up to $800million in potential profits.\n\n'To count the next four largest companies in the world as customers - Apple, Alphabet, Amazon and Microsoft - is surely a sign of a business offering a world-leading product that cannot be ignored,' he adds.\n\nAlthough Nvidia shares don't look ludicrously over-valued at the moment, they 'can't keep going up in a straight line for ever', says Derren Nathan, head of equity research at investment platform Hargreaves Lansdown.\n\nOne risk is that governments - concerned about the risks to society and even humanity itself - may attempt to clamp down on AI.\n\nRather than trying to pick individual winners by putting all your chips on one bet, experts suggest that you spread your risk by putting money into a fund with shares in Nvidia or AI more generally.\n\n'Fortunately, there are plenty of AI-themed investment funds on offer,' says Dan Coatsworth, investment analyst at investment platform AJ Bell.\n\nAs well as the Blue Whale Growth Fund, there is Polar Capital's \u00a3580million AI fund, which has Nvidia as its biggest single holding, making up 6.3 per cent of the portfolio.\n\n'The fund provides broad exposure, prioritising companies that are either key enablers or beneficiaries of AI,' says Coatsworth. These include Microsoft, Amazon, Micron Technology and Advanced Micro Devices.\n\nNvidia is also the biggest constituent of the technology stock-heavy Scottish Mortgage Investment Trust on 8 per cent. Experts say other technology funds to consider include Axa Framlington Global Technology, Fidelity Global Technology, Janus Henderson Global Technology Leaders and Allianz Technology Trust.\n\nInvesting in technology funds is easy through a stocks and shares Isa, a self-invested personal pension (Sipp) or a general investment account.\n\nBritish investors can buy American stocks through an online broker, but may pay a higher trading or administration fee. UK-based shareholders of US companies must also fill in a W-8 BEN form, which allows them to pay a reduced tax rate on the investment.\n\nSo just how did a start-up without a business plan, that was founded in a California diner, conquer all before it? And can British private investors get a slice of the action?\n\nNvidia is the brainchild of Jensen Huang - a Taiwan-born electrical engineering graduate whose parents sent him to the US as a child - and two microchip designers, Chris Malachowsky and Curtis Priem.\n\nThey founded Nvidia in 1993 at a Denny's restaurant in San Jose, in the heart of Silicon Valley.\n\nThe plan was to call their company NVision - until they found out that name was taken by a toilet paper manufacturer. Huang, who once worked as a waiter and dishwasher in a Denny's outlet for $2.65 an hour, suggested Nvidia instead, based on the Latin word 'invidia' meaning 'envy'.\n\nHe has run the company ever since, becoming one of the world's richest people in the process.\n\nNvidia's main product is a graphics-processing unit (GPU) - a wafer-thin circuit board with a powerful microchip at its core. These processors allow lightweight, energy efficient personal computers and laptops to perform a huge number of calculations at high speed.\n\nFor decades the big microchip maker was Intel, but Nvidia differs from its rival in some key ways.\n\nIntel and others make industry-standard general purpose chips known as 'central processing units' (CPUs), which handle all the main functions of a computer, producing one mathematical calculation at a time.\n\nBut Nvidia's GPU can complete complex and repetitive tasks much faster, breaking them down into smaller components before processing them in parallel.\n\nIf CPUs are delivery vehicles dropping off one package at a time, Nvidia's GPUs are more like a fleet of high-speed motorbikes spreading across a city. That made them the perfect processors to power the dawning AI revolution.\n\nUnlike Intel, Nvidia doesn't make its own chips - that's mainly contracted out to the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company. Crucially, though, Nvidia not only designs the hardware, but also the software on which they run.\n\n'What Nvidia does for a living is not build the chip - we build the entire supercomputer, from the chip to the system, to the interconnects, the NVLinks, the networking, but very importantly the software,' says Huang, 61.\n\nThis secret-sauce software package is called Cuda. Nvidia's chips originally set out to improve the computer graphics used by video gamers. Cuda's creation in 2006 allowed other, all-purpose applications to run on Nvidia's chips, too.\n\nInitially, AI wasn't one of them. In the early 2010s, AI was still a technology backwater where progress in areas such as speech and image recognition was slow.\n\nEven less fashionable were 'neural networks' - computing structures which mimic the workings of the human brain.\n\nNvidia's breakthrough came when the Cuda platform was championed by British-Canadian computer scientist and cognitive psychologist Geoffrey Hinton, dubbed the 'godfather of AI'.\n\nTwo of his students trained a neural network to identify videos of cats using just two of Nvidia's boards. Google boffins needed 16,000 CPUs to perform the feat. Machine learning had arrived.\n\nThe stunning results prompted Huang to go all-in on AI in 2013.\n\nNvidia's GPUs were soon to be found in everything from smart cars to robotics and data centres with customers ranging from Tesla to Microsoft and Amazon. One setback was a failed \u00a331billion bid to buy Cambridge-based chip designer Arm Holdings.\n\nBut Nvidia really came of age a year ago with news that ChatGPT - Open AI's chatbot - was powered by its supercomputers. This propelled the shares into orbit.\n\nThe news led to a frenzy among big tech companies and AI start-ups for Nvidia's processors, leading to shortages that could last into next year.\n\nOn May 23, bumper results that beat market expectations caused the company's value to increase by $200billion in just one day.\n\nTo meet the insatiable demand, Nvidia plans to launch a new generation of AI chips - code-named Blackwell - later this year, costing more than $30,000 each.\n\nIt can charge so much because of its stranglehold on the AI chip market, with a market share of more than 80 per cent.\n\nThis near-monopoly has turned Nvidia into a massive money-making machine, fueling potentially huge future share price rises.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", In contrast, Apple's share in the index will drop to about 4.5 percent. It is expected that US-based State Street Global Advisors will invest $10 billion in Nvidia shares, and other index-tracking funds will also boost their holdings.\n\nNvidia's stock was further boosted by Rosenblatt Securities, which raised its price target to $200, a 50 percent increase from its current value. This optimistic outlook is based on Rosenblatt's forecast of Nvidia's earnings exceeding $5 per share by 2026, driven by gains in the AI chip industry.\n\nThe company's advanced chips, including Hopper, Blackwell, and Rubin, are expected to enhance its market position, particularly in AI infrastructure.\n\nNvidia is considered one of the 'Magnificent Seven' technology stocks in the United States. {"uri": "8184070853", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "17:59:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T17:59:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T17:56:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.ign.com/articles/nvidia-market-cap-crosses-3-trillion-surpassing-apple-and-microsoft-as-worlds-most-valuable-company-update", "title": "Nvidia Market Cap Crosses $3 Trillion, Surpassing Apple and Microsoft as World's Most Valuable Company [UPDATE] - IGN", "body": "Update 06/18/2024: As reported by Bloomberg, Nvidia has become the world's most valuable company, with its market value hitting $3.3 trillion today. This surpasses Microsoft, which was formerly the most valuable company in the world at $3.15 trillion.\n\nNvidia is now a $3 trillion company - and the second-most-valuable company in the U.S. stock market.\n\nAs CNBC reports, Nvidia shares closed today up 5% to $1,224.40, giving the company a market cap of $3.01 trillion for the first time in its history. That puts it just ahead of Apple with its $3 trillion, making it the second-largest public company behind Microsoft, which has a market cap of $3.15 trillion.\n\nNvidia has seen phenomenal growth in the last few years, thanks in large part to its leadership in the AI race, becoming a leading chip supplier for companies looking to delve into the technology. According to CNBC report from earlier this week, the company's AI accelerators have between 70% and 95% of the market share for artificial intelligence chips.\n\nIn turn, Nvidia's market cap has rapidly skyrocketed over the last two years in particular. The tech company, best known for its gaming and graphics GPUs, reached a market cap of $2 trillion just this past February, becoming the first chipmaker to reach the milestone. That came less than a year after it hit the $1 trillion mark in May 2023.\n\nTo put it in perspective: as CNBC points out, Nvidia stock has soared more than 3,224% over the past five years, and it shows no signs of slowing down. The company reported first-quarter earnings of a whopping $26 billion last month, more than triple its earnings from the same period a year ago.\n\nThe company announced last month that it plans to {"uri": "2024-06-394866341", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:04:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:04:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T14:59:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/news/science/nvidia-world-most-valuable-firm-vulnerable-3120143", "title": "Nvidia is the world's most valuable firm - but it's already vulnerable", "body": "This is i on Science, a subscriber-only newsletter from i. If you'd like to get this direct to your inbox, every single week, you can sign up here.\n\nHello and welcome back to\u202f's science and tech newsletter. Our series of guest newsletters that try to untangle big issues affecting the twinned worlds of science and technology continue once more. I'm Chris Stokel-Walker, a freelance journalist and regular contributor to\u202f.\n\nThis week, we're looking at the world's most valuable company's prodigious rise. This is the story behind Nvidia, the company that launched on the stock market 25 years ago, only became a trillion-dollar firm last year, and now has supplanted tech titans Apple and Microsoft.\n\nSmall beginnings in a diner\n\nNvidia was the brainchild of first-generation American Jensen Huang, the child of Taiwanese immigrants, and co-founders Chris Malachowsky and Curtis Priem. The trio came up with their idea sitting around a table at the American diner chain Denny's in 1993.\n\nInitially called Nvision, the company first focused on developing a multimedia platform to provide a better gaming experience with more immersive audio, better graphics, and faster performance. This became Nvidia's first graphics card, a piece of computer hardware designed to better render visuals on PCs, called the NV1, released in November 1995.\n\nLater, the company moved away from graphics cards and developed what was called a graphics processing unit, or GPU. This was a specific unit within a computer designed to focus on how to show graphics on devices - to serve the burgeoning computer game market. But researchers quickly realised that the oomph of the processing power could be used to focus on the complex array of calculations required by AI models.\n\nThis proved to be the killer use case for a company that has now seen its share price rise 591,078 per cent since its initial public offering in 1999. The firm is now worth $3.3trn.\n\nBig beneficiaries of the AI boom\n\nWhen ChatGPT became the fastest-growing app in history after its initial release in November 2022, Nvidia was well-placed to benefit. The company is the key provider of the GPU chips that are used by big tech companies to power the artificial intelligence models that sit behind ChatGPT and others.\n\nAnd by being in that position, it stands to benefit - hugely - from the AI boom.\n\nBut Nvidia's position as the main company providing hardware for the AI revolution is worrying, said Mike Katell, ethics fellow at The Alan Turing Institute. \"Considering the growing importance of AI, we're witnessing an astonishing concentration of wealth and power in just one company,\" he explained.\n\nCarissa Veliz, an associate professor in AI ethics at the University of Oxford, added: \"It's a very interesting development, and very telling expression of the AI hype. I do think there's a lot of hype, and it's still to be seen if it will last.\"\n\nThe exact path of the future of AI may not yet be clear, and the major uncertainty is whether AI has been overvalued, rather than whether it is here to stay: Veliz is about to travel to Spain to advise the government there on developing their own AI model, which would likely require chips - including those by Nvidia - to train and run.\n\n\"But most of the AI hype is still based on a promise of how we will solve [a certain] problem rather than how we can solve it,\" she said. Veliz's use of AI models hasn't yet turned up an example that shows how they can live up to the promise such as improving productivity and how we live our lives, while she worries the coming regulatory crackdown on the AI industry could also stymie its growth.\n\nNevertheless, Nvidia has managed to position itself as the de facto supplier of the computer chips integral to operating AI systems. \"Nvidia's GPU chips are, in essence, the new gold or oil in the tech sector,\" said Dan Ives, managing director and senior equity research analyst at Wedbush Securities. The analyst believes \"the fourth Industrial Revolution [is] well under way\".\n\nA note of caution\n\nThere is one thing to bear in mind when considering Nvidia's blockbuster valuation, however - which is beyond the AI hype cycle. The company is often called a computer chip manufacturer. That's not entirely true.\n\nWhile it does design the GPUs that are currently powering the generative AI revolution, it doesn't actually build them. And that's the lingering issue at the back of Nvidia's business model. Nvidia takes orders for its chips - millions of them, with backlogs and waitlists reported - and then passes the manufacturing of them off to other companies to actually produce.\n\nAnd it's there where Nvidia's weakness may lie. The lion's share of Nvidia's chips is made by Taiwan-based chip manufacturer TSMC, whose own share price isn't too shabby: it's risen by 65 per cent so far this year. But the majority of TSMC's factories are located in Taiwan, which lives under the shadow of a potential invasion by China. This could ultimately disrupt supply chains.\n\nThat risk, coupled with the near-monopoly the company has on the market, should worry us all, said Katell. \"Nvidia's enormous size and wealth is troubling on many levels, but first of all is that just one company is currently capable of building sufficiently powerful processors to keep pace with the arms race that's occurring in the AI field,\" he explained.\n\nLeading the way\n\nAs interest in AI has continued to develop - data analysed by me ahead of the release of my book, How AI Ate the World, earlier this year suggested that a new news story about AI was published every 24 seconds in the first four months of this year - so has Nvidia's share price rocketed. The value of the company has nearly doubled since 1 January.\n\nThe big question, of course, is now that Nvidia has reached the top of the mountain and outstripped its competitors, can it stay there? Are we in the middle of the frothiest AI bubble we've ever seen - and is it about to burst? Or is Nvidia likely to go even further?\n\nFor Ives, it's Nvidia's game to lose. \"The godfather of AI Jensen Huang and Nvidia are leading this revolution, and it's a race to $4trn market cap with Nvidia, Microsoft and Apple battling for the top spot.\"\n\nGiven how ubiquitous AI is, and given its central importance to all our lives now, it's likely that Nvidia will manage to overcome any issues. For one thing, it's seen as too big to fail by those who have invested huge amounts of money into the AI revolution. And the company recognises that it's exposed to single points of failure - something it's working hard to avoid. It's already diversifying its production lines outside of Taiwan.\n\nThe fact that Huang is a skilled operator and leader of a business doesn't harm its chances either. So while it's vulnerable, Nvidia, thanks to its uniquely strong standing and intelligent leadership, is still in a strong position to weather the storm and continue its growth unabated.\n\nThere's a global race for the next generation of supercolliders beyond CERN's Large Hadron Collider, and it looks likely that China could come around the corner and pip European development to the post, according to this interesting Nature story.", "source": {"uri": "inews.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "inews.co.uk"}, "authors": [{"uri": "chris_stokel_walker@inews.co.uk", "name": "Chris Stokel-Walker", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Malachowsky", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Chris Malachowsky"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nvidia", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Nvidia"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graphics_processing_unit", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, This month, Nvidia achieved the distinction of being the first company to surpass Apple in terms of market capitalization by surpassing $3 trillion.\n\nNvidia shares have surged by over 170% this year, and they have continued to rise since the company disclosed its first-quarter earnings in May. The stock has experienced a surge of over nine fold since the conclusion of 2022, a phenomenon that has coincided with the advancement of generative artificial intelligence.\n\nThis industry has experienced substantial growth due to the competition among companies such as Microsoft, Alphabet, Amazon, Meta, and OpenAI for the acquisition of the processors needed to construct AI models and execute escalating workloads.\n\nIn the most recent quarter, Nvidia's data center division generated $22.6 billion in revenue, a 427% increase from the same period a year ago. This accounts for approximately 86% of the organization's total revenue.\n\nApple's stock experienced a nearly one percent decline in trading on Tuesday, resulting in a market value of $3.28 trillion. After the company's shares declined by less than a percentage point, Microsoft's market capitalization was $3.32 trillion.\n\nNvidia's initial decades were primarily characterized by its role as a hardware company, which sold chips to players to enable them to operate 3D games. In 1991, Nvidia was founded. Furthermore, it has experience with cloud gaming subscriptions and cryptocurrency mining processors.\n\nHowever, in the past two years, Nvidia's stock has experienced a meteoric rise as Wall Street has come to recognize the company's technology as the primary force behind an explosion in artificial intelligence that shows no signs of abating. Jensen Huang, the CEO of the company, has increased his net worth to over $117 billion as a consequence of the rally. This elevates him to the eleventh wealthiest individual in the world, according to Forbes.\n\nMicrosoft shares have appreciated by approximately twenty percent since the commencement of the current year. Furthermore, the artificial intelligence boom has been a significant asset to the software colossus. This is due to the fact that it has acquired a substantial stake in OpenAI and has integrated the AI models developed by the company into its most critical products, including Windows and Office.\n\nA new iteration of laptops, known as Copilot+, has been recently introduced by the company. These laptops are designed to operate its artificial intelligence models.\n\nNvidia has become the most highly valued corporation in the United States in recent years. For the past few years, the title has been exchanged between Apple and Microsoft.\n\nAs a result of Nvidia's rapid ascent, the company has yet to be incorporated into the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The Dow Jones Industrial Average is a benchmark that has historically represented the thirty most valuable corporations in the United States. It is composed of thirty equities. On January 7th, Nvidia implemented a 10-for-1 stock split, as previously announced. The company's results report was released concurrently with this announcement.\n\nIt is a price-weighted index, which implies that the benchmark is significantly influenced by companies with higher stock prices, rather than market capitalizations. {"uri": "2024-06-390853229", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-15", "time": "20:04:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-15T20:04:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-15T17:16:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://ca.finance.yahoo.com/news/nvidia-alone-accounts-more-third-171637949.html", "title": "Nvidia alone accounts for more than a third of the S&P 500's gains this year -- and it's a big risk for investors, top economist warns", "body": "Nvidia stock has continued its stunning rally this year, sending the AI chip leader's valuation past $3 trillion and making it an even bigger presence in the S&P 500.\n\nIn fact, 34.5% of the S&P 500's market cap gains so far this year can be attributed to Nvidia alone, according to Apollo Chief Economist Torsten Sl\u00f8k.\n\nShares have soared 166% in the year to date and are up more than 200% from this time a year ago. That's as the artificial intelligence craze has gripped Wall Street, and Nvidia's quarterly earnings show no sign that the rush to stock up on AI chips isn't slowing down.\n\nBut relying so much on one stock also represents a big risk, Sl\u00f8k warned.\n\n\"Such a high concentration implies that if NVIDIA continues to rise, then things are fine,\" he wrote in a note on Wednesday. \"But if it starts to decline, then the S&P 500 will be hit hard.\"\n\nBecause the S&P 500 is weighted by market cap, even relatively minor wobbles from behemoths like Nvidia, Apple, and Microsoft can move the needle on the broad stock market index.\n\nAnd as retail investors increasingly load up on S&P 500 index funds, that means exposure to Nvidia -- for better or for worse -- is growing as well.\n\n\"The bottom line is that the extreme concentration of returns in the S&P 500 makes investors more vulnerable to single headlines impacting the one stock driving index returns,\" Sl\u00f8k added.\n\nThis isn't the first time he has sounded the alarm on the stock market's dependence on Big Tech.\n\nWhen Nvidia's market cap topped $2 trillion for the first time ever earlier this year, Sl\u00f8k compared tech valuations to the bubble seen during the dot-com era.\n\n\"The top 10 companies in the S&P 500 today are more overvalued than the top 10 companies were during the tech bubble in the mid-1990s,\" he wrote at the time.\n\nOthers on Wall Street are also growing more skeptical about Nvidia's valuation and its attractiveness as an investment after the stock's epic rally.\n\nBut Nvidia stock bulls remain. Beth Kindig, lead tech analyst at the I/O Fund, sees more astronomical gains in the coming years, predicting its market cap will surge more than triple again to $10 trillion by 2030.\n\nMeanwhile, Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang continues to surprise Wall Street, most recently by laying out a rapid cadence of new AI platforms.\n\nEarlier this month, he said Nvidia plans to upgrade its AI accelerators every year as he announced the Blackwell Ultra chip for 2025 and a next-generation platform in development called Rubin for 2026.", "source": {"uri": "ca.finance.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo! {"uri": "2024-06-391578795", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-16", "time": "19:27:58", "dateTime": "2024-06-16T19:27:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-16T18:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.aol.com/5-reasons-nvidia-isnt-ai-180000355.html", "title": "5 Reasons Nvidia Isn't in an AI-Fueled Bubble", "body": "5 Reasons Nvidia Isn't in an AI-Fueled Bubble\n\nGeorge Budwell, The Motley Fool\n\nJune 16, 2024 at 8:00 PM\n\nThe stock market has a long history of creating bubbles, particularly in the technology sector. However, when it comes to Nvidia (NASDAQ: NVDA), the chip maker's eye-popping valuation may not actually be signs of a bubble. Rather, it might reflect a deeper truth about the rapidly evolving state of artificial intelligence (AI).\n\nNvidia's shares are currently trading at 77.1 times trailing earnings, a lofty valuation by historical standards and rich even for the high-growth tech sector. This has led some investors to question whether it's time to take profits on Nvidia stock. After all, the chipmaker's shares are up by a staggering 206% over the prior 12 months.\n\nImage Source: Getty Images.\n\nHowever, several lines of evidence suggest that Nvidia's growth story is still in the early innings and that AI is on track to fundamentally alter the world. Here is a look at five key tailwinds that should power Nvidia's shares even higher over the next several years.\n\nFive key themes\n\nFirst, the general population remains largely unaware of the true power of AI. This situation is set to change dramatically later this year as Apple integrates AI into its ecosystem and Amazon strives to make Alexa smarter with AI.\n\nAs a broad base of consumers begin to experience the benefits of AI in their daily lives, demand for AI-powered products and services will likely skyrocket, driving substantial revenue growth for companies like Nvidia that provide the architecture behind the technology.\n\nSecond, the pace of AI development is accelerating. The exponential growth of computing power has put humanity on the doorstep of a series of \"Gutenberg moments\", or events that completely upend the status quo.\n\nThis quickening pace of innovation implies that rivals probably won't have time to challenge Nvidia's dominant position in the AI-capable graphics processing unit (GPU) space. While competitors like Advanced Micro Devices and Intel are aiming to cut into Nvidia's dominant market share, the window of opportunity is closing.\n\nThird, the AI arms race between leading American firms, and the U.S. and China more broadly, won't allow developers time to create alternative ecosystems.\n\nThe race to achieve artificial general intelligence (AGI) is on, and Nvidia's superchips like Blackwell will likely be the primary drivers of this transformation. As companies and nations scramble to gain a competitive edge in AI, Nvidia's technology will remain in high demand.\n\nFourth, the advent of AI won't follow any rules established by prior transformational technologies like the internet or cars. AI can potentially alter human society at a fundamental level, and it will happen in less than five years.\n\nTraditional valuation metrics and historical precedents, in turn, may not wholly apply to groundbreaking companies like Nvidia.\n\nFifth, the potential applications of AI are virtually limitless, spanning across industries such as healthcare, finance, transportation, and more. As AI becomes more sophisticated and ubiquitous, it will create entirely new markets - many of which are unimaginable today.\n\nNvidia, with its cutting-edge AI technology and growing customer base, is in the catbird seat.\n\nKey takeaways\n\nNvidia's current valuation may seem high by historical standards. But it's important to consider the company's unique position in the rapidly evolving AI landscape.\n\nWith the general population largely unaware of AI's already incredible capabilities, the quickening pace of development, and an ongoing arms race, Nvidia should continue to post record-breaking revenue growth in the coming years.\n\nAfter all, Nvidia's potential is truly unprecedented as the gatekeeper to a $100 trillion AI-based economy. Viewed in this context, the growing bubble talk around the chip maker's shares seems unjustified.\n\nShould you invest $1,000 in Nvidia right now?\n\nBefore you buy stock in Nvidia, consider this:\n\nThe Motley Fool Stock Advisor analyst team just identified what they believe are the 10 best stocks for investors to buy now... and Nvidia wasn't one of them. The 10 stocks that made the cut could produce monster returns in the coming years.\n\nConsider when Nvidia made this list on April 15, 2005... if you invested $1,000 at the time of our recommendation, you'd have $808,105!*\n\nStock Advisor provides investors with an easy-to-follow blueprint for success, including guidance on building a portfolio, regular updates from analysts, and two new stock picks each month. The Stock Advisor service has more than quadrupled the return of S&P 500 since 2002*.\n\nSee the 10 stocks \"\n\n*Stock Advisor returns as of June 10, 2024\n\nJohn Mackey, former CEO of Whole Foods Market, an Amazon subsidiary, is a member of The Motley Fool's board of directors. {"uri": "8184273996", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "21:05:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T21:05:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T21:04:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/news/nvidia-stock-microsoft-most-valuable-company/", "title": "Nvidia tops Microsoft as the most valuable public company", "body": "Nvidia on Tuesday vaulted past Microsoft to become the most valuable publicly listed company in the world, highlighting its place on the forefront of Big Tech.\n\nNvidia's stock price rose nearly $5, or 3.7%, to $135.77, valuing the AI chip maker at $3.33 trillion, compared with $3.31 trillion for Microsoft and $3.29 trillion for Apple, which boasted the largest market capitalization until being surpassed by Microsoft earlier this year.\n\nNvidia shares have shot up more than 174% this year, propelled by surging investment in artificial intelligence.\n\nThe ascent of Microsoft and Apple harken back to previous technologies, but Nvdia's startling rise in recent years has been powered by surging demand for its chips, which are helping to power massive corporate spending on all things AI, and its data center business.\n\nNvidia is also a leader in graphics processing hardware, cloud services and other technologies for high-performance computing, while expanding into other emerging sectors such as robotics and autonomous driving.\n\nNvidia, which as of 2020 had annual revenue of $11 billion, now takes in more than twice that amount in a single quarter, while its profits have soared. The company's leather-jacketed founder and CEO, Jensen Huang, is feted as a visionary for a new era of innovation driven by generative AI tools like ChatGPT.", "source": {"uri": "cbsnews.com", {"uri": "8185429064", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "13:52:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T13:52:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T13:50:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://finance.yahoo.com/news/nvidia-investors-just-got-bullish-134300082.html", "title": "Nvidia Investors Just Got Some Bullish News", "body": "There has been almost nothing but good news from Nvidia (NASDAQ: NVDA) over the past four quarters. Many investors might not recall that Nvidia's revenue actually declined 13% year over year in the first quarter of its fiscal 2024 (which ended April 30, 2023).\n\nFast-forward to fiscal 2025's first quarter, when revenue exploded higher by more than 260% year over year. In conjunction with that growth, the stock price has more than tripled in the past year, and investors continue to receive positive signs that the business will keep growing. The latest bullish news should have investors thinking Nvidia still has a long runway to increase sales in its data center segment.\n\nAfter such a huge jump in sales over the past year, some investors may be wondering if Nvidia's revenue growth may have peaked. But recent news from its fellow tech company Broadcom suggests that the addressable market for artificial intelligence (AI) equipment is broad and still growing.\n\nBroadcom supplies semiconductor solutions and infrastructure that AI requires. Its products include switching solutions, accelerators, server storage equipment, and on-site and cloud connectivity offerings.\n\nLike Nvidia, Broadcom recently reported strong results for its latest quarter. Revenue from its AI-related products set a record, and made up a quarter of total sales as the top line increased by more than 40% year over year. But it's something Broadcom CEO Hock Tan said during management's conference call with investors that should make Nvidia investors more bullish.\n\nTan admitted that Broadcom wasn't going to try to compete with Nvidia in its leading position as a supplier of graphics processing units (GPUs) to provide AI systems with computing power. He acknowledged, however, that Nvidia was increasingly becoming a competitor to Broadcom on the networking side. Nvidia's next-generation Blackwell platform is just the first step. Speaking of Nvidia, Tan noted, \"They are trying to create a platform that is probably end-to-end very integrated.\"\n\nThat should make Nvidia investors confident that the AI spending being directed to the company can continue to grow for the foreseeable future.\n\nIt's notable how much Nvidia has already dominated its competitors in reaping the investments that companies are making in data center computing power.\n\nNow consider that there is yet another segment of Nvidia's business with the potential to take a similar growth trajectory. Nvidia's automotive and robotics segment has more than doubled its revenues over the last two years. While its automotive segment still contributes only a minor portion of total sales, self-driving technology is advancing and numerous automakers are already Nvidia customers.\n\nSeveral Chinese electric vehicle (EV) makers, autonomous driving technology companies, and global automakers are using Nvidia's Drive platforms. In its latest earnings report, Nvidia also noted that \"an array of partners are using Nvidia generative AI technologies to transform in-vehicle experiences.\"\n\nMost recently, U.S.-based EV maker Rivian Automotive said it would be using Nvidia's Drive Orin processors to increase computing power and improve the performance of its R1 platform vehicles.\n\nWhile the potential remains immense for Nvidia to grow sales and earnings, investors shouldn't ignore the fact that some of that expected growth is already baked into the company's current valuation. Some investors believe the stock has already risen beyond a reasonable valuation and is due for a major correction.\n\nWhile earnings are up by more than 600% so far this year, the stock followed a similar trajectory. With a forward price-to-earnings ratio of about 50 and a price-to-sales ratio of nearly 30 based on this year's projected revenue, Nvidia will need to deliver significantly more growth before the stock looks like a bargain again.\n\nWhile there are realistic paths for that to occur, the stock's rise could pause as the market waits to see what actually happens. The stock could even dip. Aggressive investors still might want to have Nvidia in their portfolios based on both its past successes and the potential for more. However, after its meteoric rise, this stock is a good candidate to buy in stages rather than deploying all the funds you plan to commit to it all at once.\n\nBefore you buy stock in Nvidia, consider this:\n\nThe Motley Fool Stock Advisor analyst team just identified what they believe are the 10 best stocks for investors to buy now... and Nvidia wasn't one of them. The 10 stocks that made the cut could produce monster returns in the coming years.\n\nConsider when Nvidia made this list on April 15, 2005... if you invested $1,000 at the time of our recommendation, you'd have $830,777!*\n\nStock Advisor provides investors with an easy-to-follow blueprint for success, including guidance on building a portfolio, regular updates from analysts, and two new stock picks each month. The Stock Advisor service has more than quadrupled the return of S&P 500 since 2002*.\n\nHoward Smith has positions in Nvidia and Rivian Automotive. The Motley Fool has positions in and recommends Nvidia. The Motley Fool recommends Broadcom. The Motley Fool has a disclosure policy.\n\nNvidia Investors Just Got Some Bullish News was originally published by The Motley Fool", "source": {"uri": "finance.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo! AI requires massive computing power, especially when used as cloud services from data centres. Demand for Nvidia's H100 accelerators helped to drive the chipmaker's sales up by more than 125pc last year.\n\n\"We believe over the next year the race to $4 trillion Market Cap in Tech will be front and center between Nvidia, Apple, and Microsoft,\" Daniel Ives, analyst at Wedbush Securities, wrote in a note.\n\n\"Nvidia's GPU chips are in essence the new gold or oil in the tech sector as more enterprises and consumers quickly head down this path.\"\n\nMicrosoft and Apple have vied for the most valuable tech company tag for the last year, with the Office Windows software giant being on top most of the time.\n\nAll three companies are currently valued within 2pc of each other, between Apple ($3.29 trillion), Microsoft ($3.32 trillion) and Nvidia ($3.34 trillion).", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8184775114", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "06:34:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T06:34:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T06:33:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.chinadailyasia.com/hk/article/586046", "title": "AI fever drives Nvidia's rise to world's most valuable company", "body": "NEW YORK - Nvidia has become the world's most valuable company following a staggering rally in its shares, underlining the outsized role investors expect artificial intelligence to play in the global economy over coming years.\n\nNvidia shares rose 3.5 percent on Tuesday, giving it a market value of about $3.34 trillion. That pushed the semiconductor bellwether past Microsoft and Apple which had been jostling for the top spots in recent days.\n\nALSO READ: Reports: US regulators to open antitrust inquiries of Microsoft, OpenAI and Nvidia\n\nThe surge in Nvidia's market value has been driven by demand for its chips, which are the gold standard in the AI space. The company's shares are up more than 170 percent this year and have risen about 1,100 percent since their October 2022 low.\n\nPreviously, just 11 US companies since 1925 have reached the top spot in market value on a closing basis, according to Howard Silverblatt, senior index analyst at S&P Dow Jones Indices\n\nBlockbuster earnings and broadening investor enthusiasm over AI are supercharging Nvidia's rally. That fervor has been reflected in Nvidia's market value, which took only 96 days to go from $2 trillion to $3 trillion.\n\nMicrosoft, one of the two other companies to reach those rarefied levels, took 945 days to go from $2 trillion to $3 trillion while Apple took 1,044 days to make the leap, according to Bespoke Investment Group.\n\nALSO READ: Microsoft offers $20 consumer AI subscription to boost business\n\nPreviously, just 11 US companies since 1925 have reached the top spot in market value on a closing basis, according to Howard Silverblatt, senior index analyst at S&P Dow Jones Indices.\n\nFortunes have diverged for past holders of the top position in recent decades. Microsoft reached No. 1 in the late 1990s but then its shares struggled for years during the early 2000s following the dotcom bubble, only to come roaring back in the latter half of the last decade.\n\nExxon Mobi became the world's most valuable company in the 2000s but its shares retreated following a downturn in oil prices.\n\nTo some, Cisco is the cautionary tale. The company's shares peaked at over $80 in March 2000 in the midst of the dotcom boom, during which investors often assigned dizzying valuations to internet-related companies.\n\nBespoke's analysts recently contrasted the trajectories of Nvidia and Cisco, whose products were seen as essential in supporting the internet's infrastructure.\n\nNvidia's impressive financial performance and forecasts have led its stock valuation, by some measures, to moderate despite the surge in its share price\n\n\"NVDA's run has been incredible, but it will need to keep growing from here and stave off competition if its stock is going to keep putting up stellar returns,\" Bespoke said in a recent note.\n\nFor now, Nvidia's earnings are supporting its stock price. Revenue more than tripled to $26 billion in the latest quarter, while net income jumped seven-fold to $14.9 billion.\n\nALSO READ: Experts: AI will boost stock market\n\nRevenue for the current fiscal year is expected to roughly double to $120 billion, and then rise another 33 percent in fiscal 2026, to $160 billion, according to LSEG data.\n\nNvidia's impressive financial performance and forecasts have led its stock valuation, by some measures, to moderate despite the surge in its share price.\n\nFor example, Nvidia's forward price-to-earnings ratio last stood at 43, according to LSEG Datastream. That is higher than the 25 level it stood at to start the year but below levels it reached for much of last year. By contrast, the S&P 500 trades at 21 times earnings.\n\nREAD MORE: Localized model gives company edge in AI battle\n\nWhile Nvidia has been the standout performer, it is not the only stock to benefit from enthusiasm about the profit potential for AI. Shares of other technology companies, including Super Micro Computer and Arm Holdings , have also risen sharply this year.", "source": {"uri": "chinadailyasia.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "China This remarkable achievement comes on the heels of Nvidia recently surpassing Apple by reaching $3 trillion.\n\nNvidia shares have risen more than 170 percent this year and jumped another notch after the company reported first-quarter earnings in May. The stock has risen more than ninefold since the end of 2022, coinciding with the emergence of generative artificial intelligence.\n\nApple shares fell 1,1 percent on Tuesday, dropping the iPhone maker to a market value of $3,29 trillion.\n\nNvidia's dominance in the AI chip market is a force to be reckoned with, as it currently holds nearly 80 percent of the market share. This business has grown exponentially as major players such as OpenAI, Microsoft, Alphabet, Amazon, Meta, and others scramble to secure the processors needed to develop AI models and handle increasingly larger workloads.\n\nIn the most recent quarter, revenue at Nvidia's data center business rose 427 percent from a year earlier to $22,6 billion, accounting for nearly 86 percent of the chipmaker's total sales.\n\nFounded in 1991, Nvidia spent its first few decades as a hardware company primarily selling gamers chips to run 3D games. {"uri": "8185286665", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "12:17:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T12:17:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T12:16:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://finance.yahoo.com/news/nvidia-stock-going-200-wake-120300225.html", "title": "Is Nvidia Stock Going to $200 in the Wake of Its 10-for-1 Stock Split? 1 Wall Street Analyst Thinks So", "body": "It's impossible to ignore the effect artificial intelligence (AI) has had on the technology landscape over the past year or so, and Nvidia (NASDAQ: NVDA) has been the standard bearer. The company's chips are at the heart of the AI revolution, providing the computational horsepower that makes it all possible. This, in turn, has sent the stock soaring, up 215% over the past year. These gains led to Nvidia's high-profile 10-for-1 stock split, which was completed just last week.\n\nAfter the stock's epic run to a $3 trillion market cap, Wall Street is reevaluating Nvidia's future prospects. There's a new price target from one analyst that should be of particular interest to shareholders.\n\nRosenblatt Securities analyst Hans Mosesmann reiterated his buy rating on Nvidia stock and increased his price to $200. That represents potential upside for investors of 53% compared to Monday's closing price, and would push Nvidia's market cap within striking distance of $5 trillion. One aspect of Nvidia's business that's being overlooked by investors is the software side. \"The real narrative lies in the software that complements all the hardware goodness,\" the analyst wrote.\n\nHe went on to suggest that demand for software will increase over the course of \"the next decade in terms of overall sales mix.\"\n\nI think the analyst hit the nail on the head. Nvidia's edge lies not only in the hardware but also in the associated software that helps provide peak performance. Cathie Wood of Ark Invest estimates that the total addressable market for AI software could be worth $13 trillion by 2030, helping illustrate the magnitude of the opportunity ahead.\n\nFurthermore, Nvidia will begin shipping its next-generation Blackwell processors later this year, which will cement the company's increasing lead in the AI chip space.\n\nNvidia's stock is currently selling for 51 times forward earnings. While that's a premium valuation, it's an attractive price for a stock that has generated gains of 27,450% over the past 10 years.\n\nThere's a long runway ahead, which is why Nvidia stock is a buy.\n\nBefore you buy stock in Nvidia, consider this:\n\nThe Motley Fool Stock Advisor analyst team just identified what they believe are the 10 best stocks for investors to buy now... and Nvidia wasn't one of them. The 10 stocks that made the cut could produce monster returns in the coming years.\n\nConsider when Nvidia made this list on April 15, 2005... if you invested $1,000 at the time of our recommendation, you'd have $802,591!*\n\nStock Advisor provides investors with an easy-to-follow blueprint for success, including guidance on building a portfolio, regular updates from analysts, and two new stock picks each month. The Stock Advisor service has more than quadrupled the return of S&P 500 since 2002*.\n\nDanny Vena has positions in Nvidia. The Motley Fool has positions in and recommends Nvidia.
