{"uri": "8183478398", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "11:27:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T11:27:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T11:18:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://finance.yahoo.com/news/anyone-topple-nvidia-king-artificial-111500078.html", "title": "Can Anyone Topple Nvidia as the King of Artificial Intelligence Investments?", "body": "You would be hard-pressed to find an investor who doesn't consider Nvidia (NASDAQ: NVDA) the pinnacle of artificial intelligence (AI) companies. Its graphics processing units (GPUs), which crunch AI workloads, are best in class by a wide margin and have been used by practically every company interested in AI.\n\nBut are there any companies that could dethrone Nvidia?\n\nPart of the fear of investing in Nvidia is wondering what will happen if and when the music stops. Right now, the company is firing on all cylinders. But the question remains: What happens when enough GPUs have been purchased to satisfy AI demand?\n\nThere are some factors influencing the answer to that question, such as the average lifespan of a GPU used for server computing. That is estimated to be around three to five years, which would mean there will be a replacement cycle. But if the demand for Nvidia GPUs is met, then the next round of AI technology might look somewhat different.\n\nIf that happens, which company could take the spot atop the AI mountain? Some might point to Advanced Micro Devices as a potential successor. AMD competes directly with Nvidia in the data center GPU space but has been getting smoked.\n\nHowever, AMD has recently generated momentum with various cloud-computing providers starting to add its GPUs as an alternative. They don't want to be devoted solely to Nvidia hardware because that would give it too much pricing power over them. But because Nvidia still has much better technology, AMD will likely only be considered as an alternative.\n\nAnother candidate is Taiwan Semiconductor, (TSMC for short), the chip foundry that supplies Nvidia and thereby makes its products possible. But TSMC also supplies chips to AMD and other companies, which makes it a neutral factor in the AI investment race.\n\nBesides, TSMC expects massive growth driven by AI demand over the next few years. In its latest conference call, management said, \"For the next five years, we forecast [AI revenue] to grow at 50% [compound annual growth rate] and increase to higher than 20% of our revenue by 2028.\" That's strong growth, but it also means Nvidia could continue its dominance since it's a key customer for TSMC.\n\nBut all of the above is just the hardware side; what about application and use?\n\nMicrosoft and Alphabet are both massive customers for Nvidia's GPUs. Not only do they have internal uses for them, but they also buy them to power their respective cloud computing services.\n\nThey also started designing their own AI chips, so they don't have to buy them from Nvidia. However, these chips are highly workload-specific, so general-purpose GPUs like Nvidia's will still account for the lion's share of computing power.\n\nSoftware companies like Palantir are also bringing AI capabilities to the masses. Its clients still need plenty of computing power to run its models, and it gives them the tools to create them. This could make the company a potential successor to Nvidia as a leading AI investment, since it will continue to see demand for its platform long after AI computing capacity is built out.\n\nBut all roads lead back to Nvidia, which is why it has been and will continue to be the most popular AI investment. Nvidia is on top of the AI world right now, and there currently doesn't appear to be any company that can dethrone it.\n\nBefore you buy stock in Nvidia, consider this:\n\nThe Motley Fool Stock Advisor analyst team just identified what they believe are the 10 best stocks for investors to buy now... and Nvidia wasn't one of them. The 10 stocks that made the cut could produce monster returns in the coming years.\n\nConsider when Nvidia made this list on April 15, 2005... if you invested $1,000 at the time of our recommendation, you'd have $808,105!*\n\nStock Advisor provides investors with an easy-to-follow blueprint for success, including guidance on building a portfolio, regular updates from analysts, and two new stock picks each month. The Stock Advisor service has more than quadrupled the return of S&P 500 since 2002*.\n\nSuzanne Frey, an executive at Alphabet, is a member of The Motley Fool's board of directors. Keithen Drury has positions in Alphabet and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing. The Motley Fool has positions in and recommends Advanced Micro Devices, Alphabet, Microsoft, Nvidia, Palantir Technologies, and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing. The Motley Fool recommends the following options: long January 2026 $395 calls on Microsoft and short January 2026 $405 calls on Microsoft. The Motley Fool has a disclosure policy.\n\nCan Anyone Topple Nvidia as the King of Artificial Intelligence Investments? was originally published by The Motley Fool", "source": {"uri": "finance.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo! Finance"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AMD", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "AMD"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TSMC", "type": "org", "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graphics_processing_unit", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Graphics processing unit"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Artificial intelligence"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computing", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Computing"}}, {"uri": needed for artificial intelligence (AI) software, and demand for its products has boosted its sales and profits over the last few years.\n\nInvestors are of the view that Nvidia's earnings can grow even more, and this has caused its share price to soar, though some have questioned its sky-high valuation.\n\nTuesday's share price rally means the market now values the company at $3.34tn (\u00a32.63tn), with the price having nearly doubled since the start of this year.\n\nNvidia stock was worth less than 1% of its current price eight years ago, however, competition among AI developers is fierce.\n\nMicrosoft, Google-owner Alphabet, Meta and Apple are just some of the tech heavyweights battling to create a world-beating product.\n\nThis competition according to BBC, benefits Nvidia, which dominates the vast majority of the AI chip market.\n\nAs such, investors believe the company will continue to surge in value as Nvidia's sales and profit figures have surpassed many analyst expectations in recent years.\n\nIn May, after its latest set of financial results were published, Quilter Cheviot technology analyst Ben Barringer said the company had \"once again cleared a very high hurdle,\" adding that \"demand is showing no signs of switching off either.\"\n\nHowever, a minority are more cautious with Barclays credit analyst Sandeep Gupta arguing in February, that Tuesday afternoon after they opened at $131.27.\n\nAlphabet (Google) and Amazon respectively came in as the fourth and fifth most valuable companies on Wall Street Tuesday.\n\nThe company's stock value has climbed throughout the first two quarters of 2024.\n\nOn Jan. 2, shares of Nvidia opened trading at $48.16.\n\nThe company's value has taken off since, thanks in large part to the popularity and potential of artificial intelligence.\n\nNvidia is among the most prominent and trusted suppliers of AI technology.\n\nAs Reuters noted, the surge in the company's value is driven by optimism among traders that AI is not only here to stay but will only become more prominent and refined.\n\nSteve Sosnick with the brokerage firm Interactive Brokers LLC told the wire service that Nvidia is currently the envy of the tech world.\n\n\"It's Nvidia's market; we're all just trading in it,\" Sosnick said shortly after the company became the world's wealthiest.\n\nAs Reuters also noted, Nvidia {"uri": "2024-06-394337475", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "07:28:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T07:28:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T06:47:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.guru3d.com/story/nvidia-becomes-worlds-most-valuable-company-amid-ai-boom/", "title": "Nvidia Becomes Worlds Most Valuable Company Amid AI Boom", "body": "Nvidia has surpassed Microsoft and Apple to become the most valuable company in the world, driven by the surging demand for processors that power generative AI systems like ChatGPT. On Tuesday, Nvidia's market capitalization reached $3.332 trillion. Analysts, according to the Financial Times, are still surprised by Nvidia's meteoric rise. The company's share price has increased by over 170 percent since the beginning of the year. Nvidia's chips have become critical for training and operating the large language models that are foundational to the current AI surge. Tech giants such as Google, Microsoft, and Amazon are eager to integrate Nvidia's new Hopper GPU series into their AI cloud services.\n\nNvidia's market capitalization of $3.332 trillion represents a remarkable milestone, reflecting its dominance in the semiconductor industry and its central role in the development of AI technologies. The rapid increase in Nvidia's stock value highlights the market's recognition of the strategic importance of advanced processors in enabling sophisticated AI applications. These processors are essential for the computational demands of large language models, which require substantial processing power for training and inference tasks.\n\nThe widespread adoption of Nvidia's Hopper GPU series by leading tech companies for AI cloud services illustrates the critical nature of these processors in supporting AI infrastructure. The Hopper GPUs are designed to handle the intensive computational workloads associated with AI, making them a key component for companies looking to enhance their AI capabilities.\n\nDespite Nvidia's impressive growth and market position, there are concerns about the long-term sustainability of the AI-driven market boom. The rapid rise in Nvidia's stock price has contributed significantly to its market capitalization, but analysts warn that such growth may not be sustainable indefinitely. The AI industry is still evolving, and while Nvidia is well-positioned to capitalize on current trends, the market dynamics could shift, affecting the company's valuation and market standing.\n\nThe strategic partnerships and acquisitions by major tech companies like Google, Microsoft, and Amazon further emphasize Nvidia's integral role in the AI ecosystem. These companies are investing heavily in AI technologies and infrastructure, and Nvidia's processors are a crucial part of their strategies. The ongoing demand for advanced AI capabilities ensures that Nvidia's products will continue to be in high demand, reinforcing the company's market leadership.\n\nSource: financial times", "source": {"uri": "8184013973", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "17:10:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T17:10:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T17:09:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.ft.com/content/1ec5523a-80ec-47ba-9f71-8765b4ae4577", "title": "Nvidia vaults past Apple and Microsoft to become world's most valuable company", "body": "Nvidia has leapfrogged Microsoft and Apple to become the most valuable company in the world, following months of explosive share price growth driven by demand for its chips and an investor frenzy over artificial intelligence.\n\nThe company's shares climbed 3.2 per cent to $135.18 on Tuesday, bringing its market capitalisation to $3.332tn and surpassing the two tech giants that have long jostled for pole position on US stock markets.\n\nNvidia has been the chief beneficiary of a boom in demand for chips that can train and run powerful generative AI models such as OpenAI's ChatGPT. In less than two years, it has been transformed from a $300bn company, grappling with a chip glut exacerbated by a cryptocurrency bust, into one of the most powerful tech companies in the world, with other Silicon Valley giants lining up to secure its latest products.\n\nIts huge share price gains have single-handedly driven about a third of the 14 per cent year-to-date increase in the benchmark S&P 500 index, in a rally that has shocked even bullish observers.\n\n\"This is animal spirits now, it's human emotion taking over,\" said Ted Mortonson, a tech strategist at Baird. \"Nvidia is a fantastic company, don't get me wrong. There are lots of drivers [for the stock]\u2009.\u2009.\u2009.\u2009but 40 per cent in a month, that's not normal.\"\n\nFounded 31 years ago to build PC graphics cards for video gamers, the Silicon Valley-based company has in the past year seen successive quarters of huge revenue growth, announcing a 265 per cent year-on-year increase in February and 262 per cent in May. Its shares are up roughly 170 per cent since the start of the year.\n\nNvidia chief executive Jensen Huang has declared that the company is at the centre of a new \"industrial revolution\", unleashing the power of generative AI to transform all sectors of the global economy with intelligent computing.\n\nGoogle, Microsoft and Amazon have all purchased its \"Hopper\" series of graphic processing units for their cloud services. Nvidia's software ecosystem, Cuda, which offers tools for developers using its chips, cements its dominance.\n\nIt is meanwhile rolling out its new generation of more powerful \"Blackwell\" chips, with Huang promising a \"one-year rhythm\" of new releases. Competitors such as AMD and Intel have launched their own competing AI chips but have yet to meaningfully eat into Nvidia's commanding market share.\n\n\"Somebody's got to be number one, and it's not like the stock for Nvidia has run up all by itself -- the financials have run up even more,\" said Stacy Rasgon, a chip analyst at Bernstein. \"I've never seen anything quite like this in terms of the actual economics that are driving it. It's pretty amazing.\"\n\nThe race to capitalise on the opportunity from generative AI has swept across the tech sector. At its annual developers conference last week, Apple joined in, announcing that its own suite of generative models would be embedded in its new operating systems, and signing a major partnership deal with OpenAI.\n\nNvidia's growing sway over broader stock indices has stoked concerns about the long-term sustainability of the market rally, but few analysts or investors are predicting a reversal in the short term.\n\nOf the 72 Nvidia analysts tracked by Bloomberg, just one rated the stock as a \"sell\".\n\n\"This top-heaviness of the market is really concerning\u2009.\u2009.\u2009.\u2009we're at levels of concentration that we haven't had since 1999 -- that's problematic,\" said Hans Olsen, chief investment officer at Fiduciary Trust, the $23bn wealth manager.\n\n\"But if you think back to the tech bubble, that went from 1997 until March 2000, it had a long runway. This one still has runway too,\" he added.\n\nNvidia has joined the dominant duo of Apple and Microsoft, which have been vying for the position of the most valuable company in the US -- and often the world -- for more than a decade. The last time a US company was worth more than both of them was in 2011 when ExxonMobil was the most valuable company in the country.", "source": {"uri": "ft.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8184784799", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "06:42:11", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T06:42:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T06:41:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.indiatoday.in/business/story/nvidia-most-valuable-company-surpasses-apple-microsoft-decoding-meteoric-rise-2555131-2024-06-19", "title": "Nvidia's meteoric rise: From gaming GPU maker to world's most valuable company", "body": "Nvidia leads AI revolution with projected revenue doubling to $120 billion\n\nOnce known for developing graphics cards for gaming on laptops and PCs, Nvidia has now clinched the title of the world's most valuable company -- a journey that's nothing short of epic.\n\nJust this Tuesday, Nvidia's shares shot up by 3.5%, pushing its market worth to a mind-blowing $3.34 trillion.\n\nThe reason behind Nvidia's rapid growth? The soaring demand for its AI-optimised chips, crucial for the development of advanced AI software and products.\n\nNvidia's meteoric rise is a clear indicator of AI's transformative potential and the company's stellar run also reflects it on Wall Street.\n\nThe company's shares have skyrocketed over 170% this year alone, and 1,100% since their October 2022 low.\n\nThis growth has been driven by Nvidia's dominance in AI technologies, especially chips, powering everything from advanced data analytics to autonomous vehicles.\n\nIn its latest quarterly report, revenue more than tripled to $26 billion, while net income surged seven-fold to $14.9 billion.\n\nThese figures not only highlight Nvidia's current strength but also reinforce its future potential in an AI-driven world.\n\nNvidia's journey from a market value of $2 trillion to $3 trillion in just 96 days is unprecedented.\n\nFor context, it took Microsoft 945 days and Apple 1,044 days to make the same leap, according to Bespoke Investment Group.\n\nThis highlights the frenzied enthusiasm surrounding AI and Nvidia's pivotal role in this space.\n\nNvidia's financial metrics are also impressive, indicating that its dream run may continue in the AI-fuelled world.\n\nAnalysts project the company's revenue for the current fiscal year to double to $120 billion, with an additional 33% growth expected in fiscal 2026, reaching $160 billion, according to LSEG data quoted in a Reuters report.\n\nMeanwhile, Nvidia's net margin stands at a strong 53.4%, significantly higher than Apple's 26.3% and Microsoft's 36.4%.\n\nDespite the rapid rise in its share price, Nvidia's forward price-to-earnings ratio is at 43. While this is higher than the S&P 500's 21 times earnings, it reflects a moderated valuation from last year's peaks.\n\nEven then, investor confidence remains solid, driven by Nvidia's leadership in AI and its consistent growth.\n\nNvidia's success is emblematic of the wider AI-driven enthusiasm reshaping the tech industry.\n\nCompanies like Super Micro Computer and Arm Holdings have also experienced significant gains, reflecting the broader market's embrace of AI potential.\n\nHowever, Nvidia's ability to maintain its growth and fend off competition will be crucial for its continued success.\n\nBespoke analysts caution that \"Nvidia's run has been incredible, but it will need to keep growing from here and stave off competition if its stock is going to keep putting up stellar returns.\"\n\nNvidia's rise to the top spot in global market value is more than a financial achievement; it's a testament to the transformative power of AI.\n\nAs the world increasingly relies on AI for innovation and efficiency, Nvidia finds itself at a distinct advantage, firmly positioned in the front seat as a leader in this space.", "source": {"uri": "indiatoday.in", "dataType": "news", The company's stock rose 3.5%, lifting its market value to about $3.3 trillion, while competitors Microsoft and Apple dipped.\n\nThe graphics chip-centric company has skyrocketed in value in the past two years, from $400 million two years ago, due to the company making it possible to create artificial intelligence systems with its graphics processing unit expertise.\n\nNvidia's chips are often used in AI systems, and the company controls more than 80% of that market, according to the New York Times.\n\nWith AI's recent rise, Nvidia has followed. The company's valuation is not entirely based on its current profits but rather on its potential, given Microsoft and Apple reported more than $21 billion in profit.\n\n\"No one else fully saw or appreciated this,\" Daniel Newman, CEO of the Futurum Group, a tech research firm, said. \"They saw the trend, built for the trend, and enabled the market. They can effectively charge whatever they want.\"\n\nNvidia's CEO Jensen Huang has been thrust into the public eye with his bold prediction that GPUs would be important to building artificial intelligence, which has paid off tremendously.\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE WASHINGTON EXAMINER\n\nThe company now ranks first in the world for its market cap, the total value of its shares, followed by Microsoft, Apple, Google, and Amazon.\n\nNvidia was originally known only among gamers and computer enthusiasts. {"uri": "8184129472", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "18:47:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T18:47:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T18:45:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://finimize.com/content/nvidia-becomes-worlds-most-valuable-company-2", "title": "Nvidia Becomes World's Most Valuable Company", "body": "On June 18, 2024, Nvidia became the world's most valuable company, outpacing Microsoft with a market cap of $3.326 trillion after shares rose 3.2% to $135.21.\n\nWhat does this mean?\n\nNvidia's meteoric rise has been one of 2024's standout stories, with its stock skyrocketing approximately 173% this year alone. In sharp contrast, Microsoft's shares have seen a modest 19% increase. This surge is largely attributed to Nvidia's dominance in the AI chip market, particularly generative AI. The Chief Market Strategist at Interactive Brokers highlights Nvidia's evolution as a market leader, while the Senior Vice President at Wealthspire Advisors warns that even a small misstep could cause a major stock correction. Hedge funds and retail investors are heavily investing in Nvidia due to thematic and leveraged funds, notes the President and Chief Investment Officer at Sarmaya Partners, who also cautions that perpetual growth is unsustainable.\n\nNvidia's stock surge has significantly impacted market dynamics, establishing it as a bellwether for AI-driven growth. Investors should monitor Nvidia's performance and the evolving competitive landscape in AI technology.\n\nThe bigger picture: AI's rising tide lifts Nvidia to new heights.\n\nNvidia's ascent underscores the transformative power of AI across industries. As the demand for AI chips grows, competition intensifies. {"uri": "8184140906", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "18:56:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T18:56:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T18:56:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.channelnewsasia.com/business/ai-fever-drives-nvidias-rise-worlds-most-valuable-company-4419821", "title": "AI fever drives Nvidia's rise to world's most valuable company", "body": "NEW YORK : Nvidia has become the world's most valuable company following a staggering rally in its shares, underlining the outsized role investors expect artificial intelligence to play in the global economy over coming years.\n\nNvidia shares rose about 3 per cent on Tuesday, giving it a market value of about $3.33 trillion. That pushed the semiconductor bellwether past Microsoft and Apple, which had been jostling for the top spots in recent days.\n\nThe surge in Nvidia's market value has been driven by demand for its chips, which are the gold standard in the AI space. The company's shares are up more than 170 per cent this year and have risen about 1,100 per cent since their October 2022 low.\n\nBlockbuster earnings and broadening investor enthusiasm over AI are supercharging Nvidia's rally. That fervor has been reflected in Nvidia's market value, which took only 96 days to go from $2 trillion to $3 trillion.\n\nMicrosoft, one of the two other companies to reach those rarefied levels, took 945 days to go from $2 trillion to $3 trillion while Apple took 1,044 days to make the leap, according to Bespoke Investment Group.\n\nPreviously, just 11 U.S. companies since 1925 have reached the top spot in market value on a closing basis, according to Howard Silverblatt, senior index analyst at S&P Dow Jones Indices.\n\nFortunes have diverged for past holders of the top position in recent decades. Microsoft reached No. 1 in the late 1990s but then its shares struggled for years during the early 2000s following the dotcom bubble, only to come roaring back in the latter half of the last decade.\n\nExxon Mobil became the world's most valuable company in the 2000s but its shares retreated following a downturn in oil prices.\n\nTo some, Cisco is the cautionary tale. The company's shares peaked at over $80 in March 2000 in the midst of the dotcom boom, during which investors often assigned dizzying valuations to internet-related companies.\n\nBespoke's analysts recently contrasted the trajectories of Nvidia and Cisco, whose products were seen as essential in supporting the internet's infrastructure.\n\n\"NVDA's run has been incredible, but it will need to keep growing from here and stave off competition if its stock is going to keep putting up stellar returns,\" Bespoke said in a recent note.\n\nFor now, Nvidia's earnings are supporting its stock price. Revenue more than tripled to $26 billion in the latest quarter, while net income jumped seven-fold to $14.9 billion.\n\nRevenue for the current fiscal year is expected to roughly double to $120 billion, and then rise another 33 per cent in fiscal 2026, to $160 billion, according to LSEG data.\n\nNvidia's impressive financial performance and forecasts have led its stock valuation, by some measures, to moderate despite the surge in its share price. For example, Nvidia's forward price-to-earnings ratio last stood at 43, according to LSEG Datastream. That is higher than the 25 level it stood at to start the year but below levels it reached for much of last year. By contrast, the S&P 500 trades at 21 times earnings.\n\nWhile Nvidia has been the standout performer, it is not the only stock to benefit from enthusiasm about the profit potential for AI. Shares of other technology companies, including Super Micro Computer and Arm Holdings, have also risen sharply this year.", "source": {"uri": "channelnewsasia.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8184099598", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "18:21:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T18:21:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T18:20:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://finimize.com/content/nvidia-becomes-worlds-most-valuable-company", "title": "Nvidia Becomes World's Most Valuable Company", "body": "Nvidia has ascended to become the world's most valuable company as of June 18, 2024, surpassing Microsoft in market capitalization.\n\nWhat does this mean?\n\nShares of Nvidia rose 3.2% to $135.21, pushing its market cap to a staggering $3.326 trillion. This remarkable climb highlights Nvidia's unprecedented influence within the technology sector, driven largely by the soaring demand for its chips pivotal to the artificial intelligence (AI) market. The company's stock has surged about 173% year-to-date, dwarfing Microsoft's 19% growth over the same period. Key insights from Sarmaya Partners reveal that both hedge funds and retail investors have been heavy buyers of Nvidia stock, a trend likely to persist with thematic and leveraged funds supporting further investment. Nvidia's strong earnings growth has been critical to its stock performance, although the reality of perpetual high growth may eventually lead to adjustments in its valuation.\n\nThe overwhelming demand for Nvidia's chips, essential for AI development, underscores the company's strategic importance to future tech growth. Nvidia's significant stock surge reflects investor confidence and its central role in advancing AI, predicting a robust market trend favoring high-growth tech stocks.\n\nThe bigger picture: Fragile high growth.\n\nWhile Nvidia's current growth trajectory places it as a formidable candidate to become the globe's largest entity, history and mathematical realities suggest that such high growth rates cannot last indefinitely. {"uri": "2024-06-393858815", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "19:00:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T19:00:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T18:29:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/nvidia-stock-already-due-more-post-split-price-target-hikes", "title": "Is Nvidia Stock Already Due for More Post-Split Price-Target Hikes?", "body": "The semiconductor giant recently announced a stock split, making it more attractive to retail investors. As analysts continue to raise their price targets to keep up with NVDA's progress, let's see if this high-flying tech stock is still a good buy right now.\n\nNvidia is Growing at a Fast Pace\n\nDespite its massive size, Nvidia is growing at a remarkable clip. In fiscal Q1 of 2025 (ended in April), Nvidia reported revenue of $26.04 billion and adjusted earnings per share of $6.12, higher than Wall Street's consensus estimates of $24.65 billion and $5.59 per share, respectively.\n\nThe chip giant also forecast sales of $28 billion in fiscal Q2, above estimates of $26.6 billion. While sales grew 262% year over year, its operating leverage enabled Nvidia to increase earnings by 461% in the last 12 months.\n\nNvidia is at the epicenter of the artificial intelligence (AI) megatrend, as Big Tech giants such as Microsoft, Google (GOOGL) (GOOG), Amazon (AMZN), and Meta (META) are all investing billions into this niche of the market to gain a first-mover advantage. These mega-cap giants are buying Nvidia's graphics processing units or GPUs, which are chips required to deploy AI-powered applications.\n\nDuring Q1, Nvidia's data center sales, which include AI chips, grew by 427% year over year to $22.6 billion. Prior to the AI boom, Nvidia generated the majority of its sales from gaming chips. Notably, Nvidia is even more optimistic about demand for its next-generation AI GPU, Blackwell, which will be added to data centers by Q4 of fiscal 2025.\n\nWhat Could Drive Nvidia Stock Higher?\n\nAccording to a CNBC report, the upcoming rebalancing of the Technology Select SPDR Fund (XLK) could attract around $10 billion in fund flows to NVDA. While Microsoft, Apple and Nvidia are all trading around a similar market cap, the diversification rules of the ETF mean that there's a limit on the cumulative weight of the stocks that account for more than 5% of the fund.\n\nAs a result, Nvidia's weight in the XLK ETF could increase from 6% to 21%. Alternatively, Apple's weight will fall from 22% to 4.5%.\n\nNVDA Stock Scores New Street-High Target Prices\n\nJust today, Rosenblatt analyst Hans Mosesmann set a new Street-high price target of $200 for NVDA, up from his prior target of $140. The new target implies expected upside of 48.6% from Monday's closing price.\n\nAccording to Mosesmann, \"the real narrative lies in the software that complements all the hardware goodness,\" and \"We anticipate this software aspect will significantly increase in the next decade in terms of overall sales mix, with an upward bias to valuation due to sustainability.\" The analyst's price target is based on a multiple of 40x forward earnings.\n\nPreviously, Susquehanna's Christopher Rolland had upped the ante on Monday to $165 from $145, based on an even richer 51.5x earnings multiple - which the analyst said is \"warranted as [Nvidia] is well-positioned to take advantage of flourishing end markets.\"\n\nBefore this week's rush of new Street-high price targets, the high-water mark belonged to investment firm Oppenheimer, which raised its 12-month target price for Nvidia to $150 from $100 on June 11, shortly after the stock's 10-for-1 stock split. Analyst Rick Schafer said the firm updated its financial model to account for the higher number of outstanding shares and the attractive roadmap for Nvidia's compute and networking businesses.\n\nOut of the 40 analysts covering NVDA stock, 35 recommend \"strong buy,\" two recommend \"moderate buy,\" and three recommend \"hold.\" Given this bullish configuration, there may be more price-target increases still to come.\n\nNvidia is valued at a premium due to its stellar sales and earnings growth. Wall Street expects Nvidia to end fiscal 2029 with adjusted earnings per share of $7.25. So, if NVDA stock is priced at 30x forward earnings, it should trade around $225 by May 2028.\n\nOn the date of publication, Aditya Raghunath did not have (either directly or indirectly) positions in any of the securities mentioned in this article. {"uri": "8184046238", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "17:36:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T17:36:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T17:36:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://techcentral.co.za/nvidia-worlds-most-valuable-company/246529/", "title": "Nvidia dethrones Microsoft as world's most valuable company - TechCentral", "body": "Nvidia became the world's most valuable company on Tuesday, dethroning tech heavyweight Microsoft, as its chips continue to play a central role in a race to dominate the market for artificial intelligence.\n\nShares of the chip maker climbed 3.2% to US$135.21, lifting its market capitalisation to $3.326-trillion, just days after overtaking iPhone maker Apple to become the second most valuable company.\n\nThe stock has surged about 173% so far this year, compared with a rise of about 19% in Microsoft shares, with demand for its top-of-the-line processors outpacing supply. Tech giants Microsoft, Meta Platforms and Google owner Alphabet are racing to build out their AI computing capabilities and dominate the emerging technology.\n\nThe surge in shares pushed the stock to a record high, adding over $103-billion to Nvidia's market capitalisation on Tuesday.\n\nIncreasing the appeal for its highly valued stock among individual investors, Nvidia recently split its stock 10-for-one, effective 7 June.\n\n\"A stock split can reduce the price per share, making it more affordable for individual investors to buy. With Nvidia doing a 10:1 stock split, retail investors are the real winners here,\" said Sam North, market analyst at investment platform eToro.\n\nThe company's market value expanded from $1-trillion to $2-trillion in just nine months in February, while taking just over three months to hit $3-trillion in June. -- Shristi Achar, Medha Singh and Ankika Biswas, (c) 2024 Reuters", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8184228349", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "20:19:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T20:19:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T20:18:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.crn.com/news/components-peripherals/2024/analysis-embraced-by-it-world-nvidia-is-now-world-s-most-valuable-company", "title": "Analysis: Embraced By IT World, Nvidia Is Now World's Most Valuable Company", "body": "Nvidia couldn't have reached the apex of the corporate world without the support of the cloud service providers, server vendors, data center infrastructure software providers and independent software vendors who have increasingly embraced its 'full-stack computing' platform.\n\nNvidia has surpassed Microsoft in market capitalization, making it the world's most valuable company, and the AI chip giant only achieved that milestone after receiving the full embrace by the largest players in the IT industry, Microsoft included.\n\nThe Santa Clara, Calif.-based company hit a $3.34 trillion market cap on Tuesday, allowing it to overtake Microsoft, as its stock price rose more than 3.5 percent. The only other company close to Nvidia in market cap is Apple, which is now valued at $3.28 trillion.\n\n[Related: Analysis: As Nvidia Takes AI Victory Lap, AMD Doubles The Trouble For Intel]\n\nNvidia couldn't have reached the apex of the corporate world without the support of the cloud service providers, server vendors, data center infrastructure software providers and independent software vendors who have increasingly embraced the company's growing portfolio of GPUs, CPUs, networking gear, server platforms and software.\n\nWhile Nvidia has long stood out due to continuous advances in its GPUs -- which have been key to providing the accelerated performance needed to make generative AI advancements possible -- a great deal of its recent success has come from its focus on evolving from a chip designer to what CEO Jensen Huang calls a \"full-stack\" computing company.\n\nStarting with the foundation of its CUDA programming model that has allowed developers to embrace GPUs for a growing number of demanding workloads, Nvidia has spent the past several years building out this stack, either by acquiring companies or developing internal capabilities, so that it could tightly integrate and tune each component, with the goal of optimizing performance and efficiency while keeping development barriers low.\n\nThese components range from GPUs and CPUs to data processing units (DPUs) and high-speed interconnects, and the company is packaging them into its own server platform designs, such as the HGX, for cloud service providers and OEMs to adopt for their own products.\n\nThis has increasingly put Nvidia behind the steering wheel when it comes to the way servers and data centers are designed.\n\nTake, for instance, Amazon Web Services' Project Ceiba, which the company said in March will become \"one of the world's fastest AI supercomputers.\" This supercomputer will be made up of Nvidia's GB200 NVL72 systems, which are multi-node, liquid-cooled, rack-scale servers that each contain 36 of Nvidia's upcoming GB200 Grace Blackwell as well as its BlueField-3 DPUs.\n\nThe GB200 NVL72 systems will also become the basis for instances powered by Nvidia's upcoming Blackwell GPU architecture from the likes of Microsoft Azure, Google Cloud and Oracle Cloud Infrastructures. And these cloud service providers plan to offer Nvidia's DGX Cloud service, which includes the company's Nvidia AI Enterprise commercial software platform as well as enterprise support, on top to aid with AI development.\n\nNvidia's influence is also strong with server OEMs, and that was most recently demonstrated by Hewlett Packard Enterprise, which on Tuesday launched a comprehensive generative AI solutions portfolio co-developed and co-branded by the AI chip giant.\n\nCalled \"Nvidia AI Computing By HPE,\" the portfolio's name further underscores how central Nvidia has become to modern data center infrastructure offerings, covering products not just for compute but also storage and networking. It even comes with a joint enablement and training program with combined market development funds for channel partners.\n\nIt's this kind of influence that allowed sales of Nvidia's data center GPUs and platforms to skyrocket last year, which led to the company surpassing semiconductor stalwart Intel in annual revenue. The company's latest earnings results show that it's not losing momentum yet.\n\nBut can Nvidia keep this up for the foreseeable future? There are several companies hoping to chip away at Nvidia's influence, and they include AMD and Intel, who both believe the market is looking for more open alternatives for powering AI and other demanding workloads. Even AWS, Microsoft Azure and Google Cloud are building competitive data center accelerator chips.\n\nEven if Nvidia loses some influence in the long run, it will have succeeded in remaking the IT infrastructure world in its image and forcing others to figure out how they can do things better.", "source": {"uri": "crn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CRN"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-394003751", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "22:44:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T22:44:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T22:05:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://finance.yahoo.com/news/1-wall-street-analyst-thinks-220534729.html", "title": "1 Wall Street Analyst Thinks Nvidia Stock Is Going to $160. Is It a Buy Around $130?", "body": "One of the big debates among Wall Street followers lately has been just how far Nvidia (NASDAQ: NVDA) stock can run. A new report from one analyst leads the charge on how high shares will go.\n\nSusquehanna senior semiconductor analyst Chris Rolland just raised his firm's price target from $145 to $160 per share. That would represent a gain of more than 20% from recent levels to a market cap of $3.94 trillion. The question for investors is how bold an outlook seems reasonable for Nvidia.\n\nIt's all about the software\n\nNvidia shares have soared by nearly 600% since January 2023, thanks to insatiable demand for its graphics processing units (GPUs). Customers can't get enough of those industry-leading processors, which they require to meet the massive computing power needs of artificial intelligence (AI) applications. Nvidia already has its next-generation chips in production, and henceforth plans to introduce new versions every year.\n\nNvidia also plans to integrate software to give customers more end-to-end solutions for data center servers. Rolland thinks that software will be a key factor that drives Nvidia's share price to his Street-high estimate.\n\nNvidia's CUDA (Compute Unified Device Architecture) toolkit allows users to develop, enhance, and deploy applications on multiple types of GPU-accelerated embedded systems. Rolland said that CUDA is \"the operating system for large language model processing and/or training as of right now.\"\n\nAggressive investing math\n\nIt makes sense to focus on software and other products beyond GPUs as potential drivers of Nvidia's future gains. After all, while demand outpaces supply for chips, production capacity remains a limitation on how much revenue Nvidia can generate from its hardware. Competition is also likely to chip away at market share.\n\nBut Rolland's valuation still appears a bit aggressive. He based that target on the stock being valued at a ratio of 51.5 times his 2025 forecast for adjusted earnings per share. I don't doubt Nvidia will keep growing its top and bottom lines. However, while it's a stock worth owning for the long term, it might not get that valuation as soon as next year.\n\nThe Motley Fool Stock Advisor analyst team just identified what they believe are the 10 best stocks for investors to buy now... and Nvidia wasn't one of them. The 10 stocks that made the cut could produce monster returns in the coming years.\n\nConsider when Nvidia made this list on April 15, 2005... if you invested $1,000 at the time of our recommendation, you'd have $802,591!*\n\nStock Advisor provides investors with an easy-to-follow blueprint for success, including guidance on building a portfolio, regular updates from analysts, and two new stock picks each month. The Stock Advisor service has more than quadrupled the return of S&P 500 since 2002*.\n\nHoward Smith has positions in Nvidia. The Motley Fool has positions in and recommends Nvidia. {"uri": "2024-06-394780509", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "13:46:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T13:46:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T10:53:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://ca.finance.yahoo.com/news/nvidia-cfo-instrumental-success-key-105353287.html", "title": "Nvidia's CFO has been 'instrumental' in success and 'key to Jensen's vision,' top analyst says", "body": "Good morning. Nvidia on Tuesday surpassed Microsoft to become the most valuable company in the world, reaching a market capitalization of $3.34 trillion to edge out Microsoft's $3.32 trillion.\n\nIn the first week of June, CEO Jensen Huang saw his firm hit a $3 trillion market cap for the first time, surpassing Apple. The Santa Clara, Calif.-based chipmaker, whose highly sought-after semiconductors help power AI-related computing tasks at massive data centers, has dominated the market. Over the past year, shares of Nvidia have surged more than 200%.\n\n\"The Godfather of AI, Jensen, and Nvidia are leading this AI revolution, and it's a race to $4 trillion market cap -- with Nvidia, Microsoft, and Apple battling for the No. 1 spot,\" Dan Ives, managing partner at Wedbush Securities, told me on Tuesday.\n\nHuang cofounded Nvidia in 1993 with Chris Malachowsky and Curtis Priem. About 34.5% of the S&P 500's market cap gains so far this year can be attributed to Nvidia alone, according to Apollo Global Management chief economist Torsten Sl\u00f8k, Fortune previously reported.\n\nOn May 22, Nvidia reported results for the quarter ended April 28, and it showed no signs of slowing down. On the earnings call, Nvidia EVP and CFO Colette Kress said revenue for the quarter was $26 billion, up 18% sequentially and up 262% year on year, and well above the company's outlook of $24 billion.\n\n\"The CFO leadership at Nvidia from Colette Kress has been instrumental in Nvidia's success with Wall Street, and is key to Jensen's vision,\" Ives told me. \"She is extremely well respected both internally at Nvidia and across the tech industry.\"\n\nKress joined Nvidia in 2013 as CFO after serving nearly 25 years in a range of finance roles at major technology companies. She previously was CFO of Cisco's Business Technology and Operations Finance organization, and she spent 13 years at Microsoft, including four years as CFO of the server and tools division.\n\nI had the opportunity to sit down with Kress in 2022, and we discussed how the rest of her career prepared her to move to Nvidia.\n\nHere's what she told me:\n\n\"My career background did serve me well. When I started at Nvidia, it was the smallest company that I'd ever worked for. It's gotten quite large, but the focus is on how do you think about the future and make sure we're ready for it to scale?\n\n\"Some of the techniques and processes have to be transformed over time as the company scales. How do we digitize manual processes? Our fast growth rate has put that front and center for us. Particularly, in my role leading finance, and the sister and brother organizations around me, I'm looking to them to say, 'Hey, we need to revise a process, how the functions work together, to create digital solutions.'\n\n\"When looking back at my career of 30-plus years, what's fascinating now is there are so many different ways to do things that never existed -- even at some of the largest companies that I've worked at in the past.\"\n\nShe now works at the largest company. and Microsoft's $3.317 trillion, while the price of NVDA stock has demonstrated strength as well, as it kept growing alongside, hitting a new all-time high (ATH) of $135.\n\nIn this context, a number of $130.29, despite some of them seeing a further climb to $200.\n\nAmong the experts that have raised their price targets on NVDA shares is Tigress Financial analyst Ivan Feinseth, who has recently increased his expectations for Nvidia stock's price by $71.50 - from the previous $98.50 to the current $170 - for the next 12 months, maintaining its 'buy' rating.\n\nAt the same time, Wells Fargo (NYSE: WFC) has updated his Nvidia stock target price, increasing it from $125 to $155, and Wedbush estimated that over the next year, the race to a $4 trillion market cap in the technology sector would continue to revolve around Nvidia, Apple, and Microsoft.\n\nAt the same time, Rosenblatt Securities went all-bullish on NVDA stock, raising its Nvidia price target from $140 to $200, projecting 5.14%, as well as the 43.05% advance on its monthly chart, as it grew a whopping 181.47% this year alone, as per data on June 19.\n\nIt is also worth noting that market expert Louis Navellier has shared his view that despite NVDA's already-staggering rise, the AI company's stock has significantly more room to grow and that it will soon target an unprecedented market cap of $5 trillion, as Finbold reported on June 7.\n\nAll things considered, Wall Street analysts' views regarding the future performance of Nvidia shares seem to be growing bullish, albeit not many of them have yet jumped Apple's stock fell more than 1%, to a value of $3.286 trillion. Nvidia's astonishing rise in market value over the past year has become a symbol of Wall Street's frenzy driven by optimism over the emerging artificial intelligence technology.\n\nAlso Read: Stock Market: Sensex, Nifty 50 Open At All-Time High; Trades Higher In Early Trade\n\nThe company's market capitalization expanded from $1 trillion to $2 trillion in just nine months in February, while it took just over three months to reach $3 trillion in June. Microsoft's share price fell 0.45%, and its market value stood at $3.317 trillion. Apple's stock price fell more than 1%, to a value of $3.286 trillion.\n\nNvidia's stock price surged nearly threefold so far this year, while shares of Microsoft soared 19% in the same period. {"uri": "8184141270", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "18:58:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T18:58:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T18:56:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.investing.com/news/stock-market-news/ai-fever-drives-nvidias-rise-to-worlds-most-valuable-company-3488728", "title": "AI fever drives Nvidia's rise to world's most valuable company By Reuters", "body": "NEW YORK (Reuters) - Nvidia (NASDAQ:NVDA) has become the world's most valuable company following a staggering rally in its shares, underlining the outsized role investors expect artificial intelligence to play in the global economy over coming years.\n\nNvidia shares rose about 3% on Tuesday, giving it a market value of about $3.33 trillion. That pushed the semiconductor bellwether past Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT) and Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL), which had been jostling for the top spots in recent days.\n\nThe surge in Nvidia's market value has been driven by demand for its chips, which are the gold standard in the AI space. The company's shares are up more than 170% this year and have risen about 1,100% since their October 2022 low.\n\nBlockbuster earnings and broadening investor enthusiasm over AI are supercharging Nvidia's rally. That fervor has been reflected in Nvidia's market value, which took only 96 days to go from $2 trillion to $3 trillion.\n\nMicrosoft, one of the two other companies to reach those rarefied levels, took 945 days to go from $2 trillion to $3 trillion while Apple took 1,044 days to make the leap, according to Bespoke Investment Group.\n\nPreviously, just 11 U.S. companies since 1925 have reached the top spot in market value on a closing basis, according to Howard Silverblatt, senior index analyst at S&P Dow Jones Indices.\n\nFortunes have diverged for past holders of the top position in recent decades. Microsoft reached No. 1 in the late 1990s but then its shares struggled for years during the early 2000s following the dotcom bubble, only to come roaring back in the latter half of the last decade.\n\nExxon Mobil (NYSE:XOM) became the world's most valuable company in the 2000s but its shares retreated following a downturn in oil prices.\n\nTo some, Cisco (NASDAQ:CSCO) is the cautionary tale. The company's shares peaked at over $80 in March 2000 in the midst of the dotcom boom, during which investors often assigned dizzying valuations to internet-related companies.\n\nBespoke's analysts recently contrasted the trajectories of Nvidia and Cisco, whose products were seen as essential in supporting the internet's infrastructure.\n\n\"NVDA's run has been incredible, but it will need to keep growing from here and stave off competition if its stock is going to keep putting up stellar returns,\" Bespoke said in a recent note.\n\nFor now, Nvidia's earnings are supporting its stock price. Revenue more than tripled to $26 billion in the latest quarter, while net income jumped seven-fold to $14.9 billion.\n\nRevenue for the current fiscal year is expected to roughly double to $120 billion, and then rise another 33% in fiscal 2026, to $160 billion, according to LSEG data.\n\nNvidia's impressive financial performance and forecasts have led its stock valuation, by some measures, to moderate despite the surge in its share price. For example, Nvidia's forward price-to-earnings ratio last stood at 43, according to LSEG Datastream. That is higher than the 25 level it stood at to start the year but below levels it reached for much of last year. By contrast, the S&P 500 trades at 21 times earnings.\n\nWhile Nvidia has been the standout performer, it is not the only stock to benefit from enthusiasm about the profit potential for AI. Shares of other technology companies, including Super Micro Computer (NASDAQ:SMCI) and Arm Holdings (NASDAQ:ARM), have also risen sharply this year.", "source": {"uri": "investing.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8180780062", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-16", "time": "18:05:22", "dateTime": "2024-06-16T18:05:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-16T18:04:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.fool.com/investing/2024/06/16/5-reasons-nvidia-isnt-in-an-ai-fueled-bubble/", "title": "5 Reasons Nvidia Isn't in an AI-Fueled Bubble | The Motley Fool", "body": "The stock market has a long history of creating bubbles, particularly in the technology sector. However, when it comes to Nvidia (NVDA 1.75%), the chip maker's eye-popping valuation may not actually be signs of a bubble. Rather, it might reflect a deeper truth about the rapidly evolving state of artificial intelligence (AI).\n\nNvidia's shares are currently trading at 77.1 times trailing earnings, a lofty valuation by historical standards and rich even for the high-growth tech sector. This has led some investors to question whether it's time to take profits on Nvidia stock. After all, the chipmaker's shares are up by a staggering 206% over the prior 12 months.\n\nHowever, several lines of evidence suggest that Nvidia's growth story is still in the early innings and that AI is on track to fundamentally alter the world. Here is a look at five key tailwinds that should power Nvidia's shares even higher over the next several years.\n\nFirst, the general population remains largely unaware of the true power of AI. This situation is set to change dramatically later this year as Apple integrates AI into its ecosystem and Amazon strives to make Alexa smarter with AI.\n\nAs a broad base of consumers begin to experience the benefits of AI in their daily lives, demand for AI-powered products and services will likely skyrocket, driving substantial revenue growth for companies like Nvidia that provide the architecture behind the technology.\n\nSecond, the pace of AI development is accelerating. The exponential growth of computing power has put humanity on the doorstep of a series of \"Gutenberg moments\", or events that completely upend the status quo.\n\nThis quickening pace of innovation implies that rivals probably won't have time to challenge Nvidia's dominant position in the AI-capable graphics processing unit (GPU) space. While competitors like Advanced Micro Devices and Intel are aiming to cut into Nvidia's dominant market share, the window of opportunity is closing.\n\nThird, the AI arms race between leading American firms, and the U.S. and China more broadly, won't allow developers time to create alternative ecosystems.\n\nThe race to achieve artificial general intelligence (AGI) is on, and Nvidia's superchips like Blackwell will likely be the primary drivers of this transformation. As companies and nations scramble to gain a competitive edge in AI, Nvidia's technology will remain in high demand.\n\nFourth, the advent of AI won't follow any rules established by prior transformational technologies like the internet or cars. AI can potentially alter human society at a fundamental level, and it will happen in less than five years.\n\nTraditional valuation metrics and historical precedents, in turn, may not wholly apply to groundbreaking companies like Nvidia.\n\nFifth, the potential applications of AI are virtually limitless, spanning across industries such as healthcare, finance, transportation, and more. As AI becomes more sophisticated and ubiquitous, it will create entirely new markets - many of which are unimaginable today.\n\nNvidia, with its cutting-edge AI technology and growing customer base, is in the catbird seat.\n\nNvidia's current valuation may seem high by historical standards. But it's important to consider the company's unique position in the rapidly evolving AI landscape.\n\nWith the general population largely unaware of AI's already incredible capabilities, the quickening pace of development, and an ongoing arms race, Nvidia should continue to post record-breaking revenue growth in the coming years.\n\nAfter all, Nvidia's potential is truly unprecedented as the gatekeeper to a $100 trillion AI-based economy. Viewed in this context, the growing bubble talk around the chip maker's shares seems unjustified.", "source": {"uri": "fool.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Motley Fool"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8184225845", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "20:17:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T20:17:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T20:16:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2024/06/18/technology/nvidia-most-valuable-company.html", "title": "Nvidia Becomes Most Valuable Public Company, Topping Microsoft and Apple", "body": "Move over, Microsoft and Apple. The stock market has a new king.\n\nOn Tuesday, Nvidia leapfrogged two of tech's most storied names to become the world's most valuable public company, according to data from S&P Global. Its ascent has been powered by the boom in generative artificial intelligence and surging demand for the company's chips -- known as graphics processing units, or GPUs -- which have made it possible to create A.I. systems.\n\nNvidia's rise is among the fastest in market history. Just two years ago, the company's market valuation was over $400 million. Now, in the span of a year, it has gone from $1 trillion to more than $3 trillion.\n\nOn Tuesday, Nvidia's share price rose 3.6 percent, lifting its value above $3.3 trillion. Microsoft and Apple both fell, ending the day trailing the Silicon Valley chip maker.\n\nYears before other big chip companies, Nvidia's chief executive, Jensen Huang, bet that GPUs would be essential to building artificial intelligence, and he tailored his company to accommodate what he believed would be tech's next big boom.\n\nHis big bet is paying off. By some measurements, Nvidia controls more than 80 percent of the market for the chips used in A.I. systems. Nvidia's biggest customers regularly jockey for orders for chips to run computers in their giant data centers, and are building their own A.I. chips so they are not so dependent on one supplier.\n\n\"No one else fully saw or appreciated this,\" said Daniel Newman, chief executive of the Futurum Group, a tech research firm. \"They saw the trend, built for the trend and enabled the market. They can effectively charge whatever they want.\"\n\nNvidia's ascent has made Mr. Huang a celebrity in the tech world. After a computer conference in Taiwan early this month, he was surrounded by attendees who wanted his autograph, including a woman who asked him to sign her chest.\n\nThe company's rise is reminiscent of dot-com era titans like Cisco and Juniper Networks, which built the equipment that ran communications networks for the internet. Cisco's shares increased more than a thousandfold between its initial public offering in 1990 and 2000, when it briefly became the world's most valuable company.\n\nThe speed at which Nvidia's value has grown has been startling. Apple crossed $1 trillion in August 2018 and became the first $3 trillion company last June. Microsoft also took nearly five years to climb from $1 trillion to $3 trillion.\n\nBut Nvidia's investors are betting more on its potential than on its current profits. Microsoft and Apple generate more than $85 billion in annual profits, while Nvidia generates $42.6 billion.\n\n\"The numbers have gotten so big so quickly that people worry: Is this sustainable?\" said Stacy Rasgon, an analyst with Bernstein Research. \"If the return on A.I. turns out to not be there, then the whole thing comes crumbling down.\"\n\nThis is a developing story. AI boom lifts chip maker above Microsoft as most valued firm", "body": "US chip maker Nvidia stockes soared 3 per cent on Tuesday as the company supplanted Microsoft as the world's most valued firm. In just nine months, Nvidia increased its market cap from $1 trillion to $2 trillion in February. And it took only three months for the firm to cross $3 trillion.\n\nThe latest rally in Nvidia market cap comes amid the company's decision to split its stock 10-for-1 ratio, drawing more individual investors to jump on the bandwagon. The stock zoomed 180 per cent in 2024 compared to 19 per cent climb by Microsoft.\n\nThe top second and third companies, Microsoft and Apple, saw their share prices slipping 0.45 per cent and 1 per cent respectively on Tuesday.\n\nAmid growing focus on AI, several tech giants have shifted their priority to the sector in a bid to claim their dominance in the market. {"uri": "2024-06-393863116", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "19:05:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T19:05:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T14:48:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/top-news/articles/2024-06-18/ai-fever-drives-nvidias-rise-to-worlds-most-valuable-company", "title": "AI Fever Drives Nvidia's Rise to World's Most Valuable Company", "body": "NEW YORK (Reuters) - Nvidia has become the world's most valuable company following a staggering rally in its shares, underlining the outsized role investors expect artificial intelligence to play in the global economy over coming years.\n\nNvidia shares rose about 3% on Tuesday, giving it a market value of about $3.33 trillion. That pushed the semiconductor bellwether past Microsoft and Apple, which had been jostling for the top spots in recent days.\n\nThe surge in Nvidia's market value has been driven by demand for its chips, which are the gold standard in the AI space. The company's shares are up more than 170% this year and have risen about 1,100% since their October 2022 low.\n\nBlockbuster earnings and broadening investor enthusiasm over AI are supercharging Nvidia's rally. That fervor has been reflected in Nvidia's market value, which took only 96 days to go from $2 trillion to $3 trillion.\n\nMicrosoft, one of the two other companies to reach those rarefied levels, took 945 days to go from $2 trillion to $3 trillion while Apple took 1,044 days to make the leap, according to Bespoke Investment Group.\n\nPreviously, just 11 U.S. companies since 1925 have reached the top spot in market value on a closing basis, according to Howard Silverblatt, senior index analyst at S&P Dow Jones Indices.\n\nFortunes have diverged for past holders of the top position in recent decades. Microsoft reached No. 1 in the late 1990s but then its shares struggled for years during the early 2000s following the dotcom bubble, only to come roaring back in the latter half of the last decade.\n\nExxon Mobil became the world's most valuable company in the 2000s but its shares retreated following a downturn in oil prices.\n\nTo some, Cisco is the cautionary tale. The company's shares peaked at over $80 in March 2000 in the midst of the dotcom boom, during which investors often assigned dizzying valuations to internet-related companies.\n\nBespoke's analysts recently contrasted the trajectories of Nvidia and Cisco, whose products were seen as essential in supporting the internet's infrastructure.\n\n\"NVDA's run has been incredible, but it will need to keep growing from here and stave off competition if its stock is going to keep putting up stellar returns,\" Bespoke said in a recent note.\n\nFor now, Nvidia's earnings are supporting its stock price. Revenue more than tripled to $26 billion in the latest quarter, while net income jumped seven-fold to $14.9 billion.\n\nRevenue for the current fiscal year is expected to roughly double to $120 billion, and then rise another 33% in fiscal 2026, to $160 billion, according to LSEG data.\n\nNvidia's impressive financial performance and forecasts have led its stock valuation, by some measures, to moderate despite the surge in its share price. For example, Nvidia's forward price-to-earnings ratio last stood at 43, according to LSEG Datastream. That is higher than the 25 level it stood at to start the year but below levels it reached for much of last year. By contrast, the S&P 500 trades at 21 times earnings.\n\nWhile Nvidia has been the standout performer, it is not the only stock to benefit from enthusiasm about the profit potential for AI. Shares of other technology companies, including Super Micro Computer and Arm Holdings, have also risen sharply this year.\n\n(Reporting by Lewis Krauskopf in New York; Additional reporting by Saqib {"uri": "8181681044", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "10:15:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T10:15:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T10:13:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://finance.yahoo.com/news/insiders-selling-nvidia-stock-100700017.html", "title": "Insiders Are Selling Nvidia Stock. Should You?", "body": "When key insiders buy shares of their company, they're probably confident about its future. Sure, that confidence could be misplaced. However, most investors see insider buying as a positive sign.\n\nBut it can be a much different story when key insiders sell shares. In some cases, such moves could hint that they aren't optimistic about the stock's future -- at least over the near term.\n\nThat leads me to Nvidia (NASDAQ: NVDA). The stock has been on a roll, skyrocketing more than seven times over the last three years and soaring more than 160% so far in 2024. However, Insiders are selling their shares of Nvidia. Should you?\n\nSince the beginning of May, 10 Form 144 filings have been reported by Nvidia to the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). There are two important things to know about Form 144. First, it's a notice of the proposed sale of securities. Second, it's only used when there's a planned sale of 5,000 or more shares or an aggregate amount of over $50,000.\n\nThe most prominent person selling Nvidia stock is the company's CEO, Jensen Huang. Nvidia notified the SEC that Huang planned to sell 120,000 shares on June 13, 2024. At the market close on that date, this transaction would have been worth around $15.5 million.\n\nHuang wasn't the only Nvidia executive selling shares. Executive vice president of operations Deborah Shoquist sold 41,140 shares worth more than $45 million on June 3, 2024.\n\nSeveral members of Nvidia's board of directors also got in on the action. Dawn Hudson sold a total of 25,000 shares on three separate occasions since May 29, 2024. Board members Tench Coxe, John Dabiri, Michael McCaffery, Brooke Seawell, and Mark Stevens also sold some of their Nvidia shares in recent weeks.\n\nThese insider sales could be alarming to some investors. To use an old saying: Are the rats fleeing a sinking ship? Nope. There's more to the story.\n\nThe shares Huang sold were part of his executive compensation package. Specifically, they were restricted stock units (RSU) and performance stock units (PSU). Company CEOs frequently sell such shares when they're allowed to do so.\n\nImportantly, Huang owned nearly 93.5 million shares of Nvidia as of March 25, 2024. That's almost 3.8% of the company's outstanding shares. His recent sales were only a drop in the bucket compared to his total holdings. Huang still has plenty of skin in the game.\n\nMost of the other sales (including the ones by Shoquist and several board members) were also of restricted stock units. Investors shouldn't be too concerned about these transactions.\n\nI don't think the recent insider sales of Nvidia are a reason for outsiders to sell the stock. However, there could be some reasons for you to consider selling.\n\nNvidia's jaw-dropping gains might have caused the stock to make up a worrisome percentage of your overall portfolio. Some investors might want to trim their positions as a result.\n\nMy colleague Sean Williams predicts that Nvidia stock is poised to plunge by at least 50%. If you agree with his rationale, selling soon makes sense.\n\nHowever, Nvidia's underlying business remains strong. The company continues to execute exceptionally well. The demand for its graphics processing units isn't waning. Those are great reasons to hang on to a stock.\n\nBefore you buy stock in Nvidia, consider this:\n\nThe Motley Fool Stock Advisor analyst team just identified what they believe are the 10 best stocks for investors to buy now... and Nvidia wasn't one of them. The 10 stocks that made the cut could produce monster returns in the coming years.\n\nConsider when Nvidia made this list on April 15, 2005... if you invested $1,000 at the time of our recommendation, you'd have $808,105!*\n\nStock Advisor provides investors with an easy-to-follow blueprint for success, including guidance on building a portfolio, regular updates from analysts, and two new stock picks each month. The Stock Advisor service has more than quadrupled the return of S&P 500 since 2002*.\n\nKeith Speights has no position in any of the stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool has positions in and recommends Nvidia. The Motley Fool has a disclosure policy.\n\nInsiders Are Selling Nvidia Stock. {"uri": "8185311198", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "12:33:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T12:33:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T12:32:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.fool.com/investing/2024/06/19/is-nvidia-stock-going-to-200-in-the-wake-of-its-10/", "title": "Is Nvidia Stock Going to $200 in the Wake of Its 10-for-1 Stock Split? 1 Wall Street Analyst Thinks So | The Motley Fool", "body": "Wall Street analysts are boosting their price targets in the wake of Nvidia's high-profile stock split.\n\nIt's impossible to ignore the effect artificial intelligence (AI) has had on the technology landscape over the past year or so, and Nvidia (NVDA 3.51%) has been the standard bearer. The company's chips are at the heart of the AI revolution, providing the computational horsepower that makes it all possible. This, in turn, has sent the stock soaring, up 215% over the past year. These gains led to Nvidia's high-profile 10-for-1 stock split, which was completed just last week.\n\nAfter the stock's epic run to a $3 trillion market cap, Wall Street is reevaluating Nvidia's future prospects. There's a new price target from one analyst that should be of particular interest to shareholders.\n\nRosenblatt Securities analyst Hans Mosesmann reiterated his buy rating on Nvidia stock and increased his price to $200. That represents potential upside for investors of 53% compared to Monday's closing price, and would push Nvidia's market cap within striking distance of $5 trillion. One aspect of Nvidia's business that's being overlooked by investors is the software side. \"The real narrative lies in the software that complements all the hardware goodness,\" the analyst wrote.\n\nHe went on to suggest that demand for software will increase over the course of \"the next decade in terms of overall sales mix.\"\n\nI think the analyst hit the nail on the head. Nvidia's edge lies not only in the hardware but also in the associated software that helps provide peak performance. Cathie Wood of Ark Invest estimates that the total addressable market for AI software could be worth $13 trillion by 2030, helping illustrate the magnitude of the opportunity ahead.\n\nFurthermore, Nvidia will begin shipping its next-generation Blackwell processors later this year, which will cement the company's increasing lead in the AI chip space.\n\nNvidia's stock is currently selling for 51 times forward earnings. {"uri": "8183607306", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "12:43:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T12:43:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T12:40:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.fool.com/investing/2024/06/18/can-anyone-topple-nvidia-as-the-king-of-artificial/", "title": "Can Anyone Topple Nvidia as the King of Artificial Intelligence Investments? | The Motley Fool", "body": "You would be hard-pressed to find an investor who doesn't consider Nvidia (NVDA -0.68%) the pinnacle of artificial intelligence (AI) companies. Its graphics processing units (GPUs), which crunch AI workloads, are best in class by a wide margin and have been used by practically every company interested in AI.\n\nBut are there any companies that could dethrone Nvidia?\n\nPart of the fear of investing in Nvidia is wondering what will happen if and when the music stops. Right now, the company is firing on all cylinders. But the question remains: What happens when enough GPUs have been purchased to satisfy AI demand?\n\nThere are some factors influencing the answer to that question, such as the average lifespan of a GPU used for server computing. That is estimated to be around three to five years, which would mean there will be a replacement cycle. But if the demand for Nvidia GPUs is met, then the next round of AI technology might look somewhat different.\n\nIf that happens, which company could take the spot atop the AI mountain? Some might point to Advanced Micro Devices as a potential successor. AMD competes directly with Nvidia in the data center GPU space but has been getting smoked.\n\nHowever, AMD has recently generated momentum with various cloud-computing providers starting to add its GPUs as an alternative. They don't want to be devoted solely to Nvidia hardware because that would give it too much pricing power over them. But because Nvidia still has much better technology, AMD will likely only be considered as an alternative.\n\nAnother candidate is Taiwan Semiconductor, (TSMC for short), the chip foundry that supplies Nvidia and thereby makes its products possible. But TSMC also supplies chips to AMD and other companies, which makes it a neutral factor in the AI investment race.\n\nBesides, TSMC expects massive growth driven by AI demand over the next few years. In its latest conference call, management said, \"For the next five years, we forecast [AI revenue] to grow at 50% [compound annual growth rate] and increase to higher than 20% of our revenue by 2028.\" That's strong growth, but it also means Nvidia could continue its dominance since it's a key customer for TSMC.\n\nBut all of the above is just the hardware side; what about application and use?\n\nMicrosoft and Alphabet are both massive customers for Nvidia's GPUs. Not only do they have internal uses for them, but they also buy them to power their respective cloud computing services.\n\nThey also started designing their own AI chips, so they don't have to buy them from Nvidia. However, these chips are highly workload-specific, so general-purpose GPUs like Nvidia's will still account for the lion's share of computing power.\n\nSoftware companies like Palantir are also bringing AI capabilities to the masses. Its clients still need plenty of computing power to run its models, and it gives them the tools to create them. This could make the company a potential successor to Nvidia as a leading AI investment, since it will continue to see demand for its platform long after AI computing capacity is built out.\n\nBut all roads lead back to Nvidia, which is why it has been and will continue to be the most popular AI investment. Nvidia is on top of the AI world right now, and there currently doesn't appear to be any company that can dethrone it.", "source": {"uri": "fool.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Motley Fool"},
